  279. I've been anxiously awaiting this order so I could begin using it right away on my unwanted facial hair (chin and upper lip) and finally made the plunge to purchase this. The description on Amazon includes &#34;Each 1,500-flash cartridge can deliver two to three full body treatments (underarms, lower legs, bikini area).&#34; and &#34;unwanted body hair&#34;. The box says, &#34;Contraindications: DO NOT USE ON THE FACE...&#34; While this is accurate, it took the actual words in the instruction manual on p. 12, &#34;DO NOT use on the face&#34; for me to realize this was STRICTLY for body which means &#34;below the neck&#34;!! UGH!!! If the Amazon description had had these words, I would not have purchased it. Now, I am considering trying it anyway on my face, but I probably won't because I have sensitive skin and would be afraid of blisters or skin darkening. So, the rating is not actually reflective of the product at all, but of the lack of the specific words for NOT using on the FACE. It's my fault, for assuming &#34;body&#34; included face. Oh well. I wanted to let others know about this in case you were considering purchase. The full text says &#34;DO NOT USE ON face, head, ears, or neck, DO NOT USE on or around the eyes, eyebrows, or eyelashes, DO NOT USE on tattoos, dark brown/black spots such as freckles, birthmarks, moles, or warts, DO NOT USE on nipples genitalia, or around the anus.&#34; So, back to the drawing board to look for a product I CAN use on my face. UPDATE one week later: I decided to keep it after I came back and read other people's reviews who used it on their faces. I wonder the same as one of the reviewers that said someone would probably use it improperly on their face and blind themselves which is why they couldn't approve it for the face. So, I started treatment on my chin to see how it goes before moving to my upper lip. I have sensitive skin and past sun burns and waxing in which some skin was ripped off have left dark splotches on my skin on the upper lip. So, I want to try the chin hairs first to see how my skin responds. Will post updates after the first three treatments which are supposed to be two weeks apart..... UPDATE many months later: Well, I used it exactly according to directions. I do see a lessening of facial hair, but I am still tweezing and shaving, so it doesn't eliminate--just like everything else I've tried (professional laser treatments included). Facial hair is relentless! I do want to tell people that I tightly close my eyes AND cover tightly with my free hand when I treat my upper lip and chin. I can still see the red flash even through all that. I don't know anything about this type of light to tell you if that's really bad, but do exercise some caution. It hasn't left any other marks on my skin. I haven't had any side effects from it such as reddening of the skin, no burning, nothing. So, I'm very happy about that. It's very quick. I found that I can set it higher (3 or 4) to do my big toes and I don't feel a &#34;zing&#34;. I keep the setting at a 2 for my face. Best wishes. I changed my rating from a 2 star to a 3 star. If I didn't have to tweeze still, I'd have given it a 5 star. I highly doubt there is anything that completely eliminates facial hair. If there is, tell me please.

  293. The unit seems to be very well built, however, the process of hair removal is far more involved than the Remington company claims. It will take a person close to one year to get rid of heavily haired areas, many replacement cartridges and persistence. It can be done, but not in a low number of sessions as the company will advertise. There is some tingle every time the light flashes, but nothing very painful....soon you will use the maximum setting as the area accustoms itself to the treatment. Some rash may be experienced on the first couple sessions only. Once accomplished, the revealed skin of the particular area is left very smooth and soft.
  294. Since about sixth grade I've had dark hair on my belly and I've tried EVERYTHING to get rid of it: shaving, waxing, sugaring, plucking, using depilatory creams, and nothing ever helped. I ended up getting a lot of scars from ingrown hairs and I felt awful about how my stomach looked. I ordered this about 3 months ago as a last resort and I'm so happy. For the first few times, I used it every 2 weeks like it says but I now use it every week. I went from having pretty dark, thick belly hairs to having very few lighter, thinner hairs in 3 months! I've also started using it on my chin (even though it says not to use on the face) but I haven't been using it there as much so I haven't seen a lot of progress.   295. As I progressed in to menopause I started growing a full out manstache! Thick black hair like a man!! Even though I shaved it off I had a literal 5 o'clock shadow by the end of the day. I DID NOT shave beforehand so that the laser could find the dark hair and get after it. The pain for me was minimal and I worked my way up to the highest setting after about a week. A little pain is a small price to pay for being hair free. After 2 months I am 70% hair free on my upper lip and will continue to use the light pro for maintenance.   298. Tip: If you're having problems getting the unit to unlock, don't press your skin against the sensor. It should just touch it or \\"hover\\" above it. I had problems unlocking my unit, which leads me to my biggest complaint so far....Remington's customer service.<br /><br />I haven't even had a chance to do a treatment to be able to speak to the unit effectiveness at hair removal. I have spent 2 weeks getting in touch with Remington. First, they only open 8AM-4PM central time, M-F and closed on holidays. I usually arrive home from work around 4:30 eastern time, by that time Remington's \\"wait\\" time is 45 minutes! I don't know why, because when you call any other time they answer the phone right away. Then of course they want the unit with you while you're on the phone. They actually told me to take it into work with me. I was going to give up and just send it back for my refund because they just had no solution for the common working person.<br /><br />A snow day kept me home so I was to call, with my unit, during their unreasonable hours. They didn't tell me not to press my skin against the unit, they just told me my skin wasn't compatible and to send it back! No where in the instructions, their website, or the video that comes with it does it state you could be \\"too white\\". That was the reasoning they gave me. I'm not pasty white, but I'm definitely not tanned. If I knew there was a possibility that fair skin could cause an issue, I never would have purchased the unit in the first place.<br /><br />After some more trial and error and the thought of having to pay to ship the unit back, I finally realized if you just lay your skin over the sensor, not press it - it will actually work. Needless to say I'm keeping the unit. Remington's customer service is a joke, don't waste your time trying to troubleshoot with them. My other frustration was the timeline I am on. I received this as a Christmas present, so it was purchased BEFORE Christmas, and I didn't receive it until 30 days into the trial period. Remington was not willing to take that into consideration....the 90 day guarantee is 90 days from purchase, period.
  299. fast shipping! good product. it is all that I expected it to be! works well and light has lasted long so far.
  300. I'm still in the process of evaluating this product. I purchased this as a NEW PRODUCT but the original light only lasted a short time. I have already replaced the I-light. I purchased 2 replacements and have had problems with the plug connections. I have to use a pencil eraser on the prongs to clean them from naturally occurring insulators. I still have to shave but the hair is thinner, lighter, and I'm not as concerned about reoccurring skin infections around old scars.
  301. Okay,<br />I was debating between a 4 and 5 star but I'm giving it a 5 because I really think this beats out other hair removal options on the market today. I do think there could be improvements but that would probably cause the cost to go way up so from a product design standpoint I think they made the best decisions they could for the cost.<br /><br />I bought this well over a year ago- used on everything for several months with good results. I am fair skinned and have dark thick hair. On areas with thicker hair - like bikini area it was splotchy but still effective over time and with patience. The biggest advantage and why I love this is that unlike almost all other options (shaving, waxing, epilating ...Yeow), this is the only option I have found that not only doesn't cause ingrown hairs but actually helps them heal if you already have them. I stopped using it because I felt it took too much time and started using a very high quality epilator with initial good results but I was plagued with in-grown hairs since. Talk about unsightly- it looked like I had bug bites all the time. I have since gone back to the Remington I-light and I'm so glad I did. The ingrown hairs are gone with no sign of new ones. My legs and underarms are so much softer and even though I still shave, I don't have razor burn or unsightly bumps everywhere. I honestly believe it improves your skin quality...not sure how that's possible with just a flash of a bright light but it's true for me. I have not had any issues with the cartridges being bad and I've gone through about 5 or 6.<br /><br />Biggest opportunity for improvement?<br />- Have different sized cartridges and make the area that receives the light larger on one option so it doesn't take so darn long to do large body parts. I would love to tackle hubbies back but I feel like I'd need to take a vacation day to do it.<br /><br />- Allow the flash to occur even if it's not completely flat. I get a lot of disappointing beepswhen I'm trying to do my ankles and knees, which then takes longer too.<br /><br />- Create an entire body suit with IPL so I could just jump in, flash my whole body from the neck down and jump out. I know it would hurt like heck for about 30 seconds but it would so totally be worth it.<br /><br />Thank you Remington for your awesome product!!!
  302. It is expensive, but it works. I have used it 3 or 4 times over 8 weeks on my problem areas and the hair has not come back for several days now. The downside of the product is that it is easy to miss spots, so you have to go slow and really pay attention to where you have been. I have used it on my face, chin and chest, even though it isn't recommended for these areas and it has worked fine. It is a little painful, but it is over soon, it is best to set it on the highest you can stand. It did make my skin red for a little while, maybe an hour, but that went away with a cool washcloth and some aloe lotion.

  306. Today, I am completing my third treatment (1 every two weeks as directed) and I am now ready to write my review.<br /><br />THE PURCHASE: I was very hesitant to spend this amount of money, without any guaranteed. But, considering the price of laser treatments at salons, I just gave it a shot. I do not regret my decision.<br /><br />TREATMENT: The treatment takes some time, considering you have to shave and then treat the areas you wish to be &#34;Hair-free&#34;. However, considering you would normally shave anyway....The process is as long as it should be. The bright light is expected, but does not hurt the eyes. As long as you are not looking at it too closely--just look away once you click the flash button. I would rate the pain a 3 out of 10. It is a light sensation of burning, or a rubber-band snap.<br /><br />RESULTS: After my second treatment, I have noticed some changes. I used to shave every other day, and the treatment reduced that frequency. BUT I could still feel the hairs, they were not completely gone. Considering my hair is thick, and dark, I did not expect it to be all gone so quickly.<br /><br />Overall, I am satisfied with my purchase and I feel optimistic about the next few weeks. I will update if needed

I've had zero detectable results. Now it just sits under my sink collecting dust. Maybe I'll give it to my next girlfriend or something.
  311. Let me start off by saying that I have had laser hair removal done professionally so I am familiar with the process. Imagine my delight, then, when I first used this product and it felt and smelled (gross, but true) the same as having IPL done at the salon. I had never had laser hair removal done on my legs prior to buying the I-Light pro so, in the interest of science, I did one leg and left the other as-is, shaving both legs at the same time but only IPL'ing the left leg. Two weeks after the first treatment I was blown away by the difference. I'm now done 2 treatments and am so impressed! I will leave the right leg for the next 3 months or so to monitor the true effect but, in the meantime, I've moved on to pretty much every other area, since it's working so well. The armpits hurt like a son of a gun but, having had salon treatments, I knew this would be the case. So, so happy with this purchase. And I love that the light can be replace, verses a product like the Tria which is useless after the bulb runs out. Highly recommend! Will try and remember to come back and give a 3, 6 and 9 month update on leg comparisons.
  312. First off, this hurts like hell on any sensitive area (like the private area lol)<br /><br />I used this on my arms, the first time on level 2, then 3 more times on level 5. Hair is still growing back like usual.<br /><br />So far, I have spent more money on this machine than shaving in my entire 29 years of life. Stick with real laser hair removal..
  313. Thusfar I have had pretty good success with this product. At first I was quite disappointed but after a month of using it every other day the hair is actually starting to just randomly fall out. My skin is quite pale and my hair is a dark brown so I'm fairly ideal for IPL. I'm also male, and have really thick coarse hair on my chest and shoulders which is where I mainly used this. Basically I'm a prime candidate for frying hair haha A little bit about this product however.... Remington seems to compare it a lot to professional systems, which it should not. Remington did not design this product actually. The original product patent is under Shaser Inc, Shaser Inc was formerly known as Shaser BioScience. Shaser BioScience originally designed this as a 3rd party consultation separate from Remington and Spectrum Brands. Spectrum currently owns Shaser BioScience, known just as Shaser Inc now. To add another twist to the tale Shaser Inc. currently has a lawsuit opened against it by Dr. Harvey Jay, a doctor whom has specialized in laser therapy for a number of things, in this particular case, hair removal. The patents owned by Dr. Jay discussing the technology behind low-energy IPL are: US Patent #6,824,542, # 6,916,316, #7,175,617, #7,553,308, and #8,393,330 The patents owned by Shaser Inc. discussing the actual product itself are: US D670397 S1 and US 8,480,721, among about 22 other language translations and variations The reason I mention patents is because they reveal a huge quantity of information about this system and some really shifty advertising scams by Remington. The hair reduction of 48% after 6 months that Remington quotes is from Smith et al. in the journal 'Lasers in Medical Surgery', titled \\"Long-term results of hair photo-epilation\\" published 1998. I could not find any study done by Remington at all and the numbers coincidentally match up to the decimal so I assume that's the study they quote. That was done using professional systems of course, and it was done over 15 years ago. A little bit more about the patents.... In Dr. Jay's patents he further explains that follicular damage is an UNINTENDED side effect of low-energy IPL. Any permanent removal is actually an accident and the system is designed not to do it. I'll give a direct quote from Dr. Jay's patents: \\"Thus, in contrast to prior methods, which are aimed at completely destroying the hair follicle, the present method contemplates only a partial destruction of the follicles or, alternatively, a destruction of the hair inside the follicles. In either case, the hair will grow and again appear on the treated surface in the absence of additional controlled light application\\" Now even more about the patents.... The nice thing about Remington not having actually designed this system but instead only facilitating the sale of it is that it's quite easy to \\"hack\\" the machine. The little EEPROM chip inside every replacement xenon flash tube contains current # of flashes, total flashes, manufacturing date, and initial energy of the lamp. The machine dynamically adapts the energy to the lamp, theoretically you could solder any xenon flash tube and the machine dynamically adapts to determine the required voltage and capacitance to output light. Very neat system actually. I was more impressed by that then what the product was actually intended to do since that's actually some really complicated circuitry haha You can hack the little EEPROM chip and as long as you leave a minimum of one property about the lamp then the system will run. You can wipe the flash count, energy, etc. and just leave the manufacturing date and you can get unlimited flashes (or at least until the bulb explodes). I just used Bus Pirate v3 to modify the eeprom chip, it's a DS2431, one of the simplest EEPROM chips out there, very easy to read and modify. It can be modified by either bus pirate v3+, a raspberry pi, or an arduino fairly easily. But if you do that be warned thateventually the bulb will literally explode. It's housed fairly safe inside the machine so no glass really gets anywhere but if you're scared of light bulbs exploding then don't mess with the flash count. The system is set to do 4 pulses of 7ms length at 3.5 Joules each, 3ms delay between pulses giving a total of 7 J/cm^2 The J/cm^2 is a value you will never see outside the pseudoscientific realm that is hair removal. In reality it's 7 Watts of power not 7 Joules, a joule is a watt-second but you drop the second due to multiplying by the frequency hence giving watts... But anyway,The actual output is 14-16W of power. Due to the machines ability to dynamically adapt and the EEPROM containing modifications to energy output for each individual replacement bulb, Remington rated the system as between 7-8J/cm^2, meaning you'll get between 14-16J (err... watts) in the 1x2cm filter window applied to your skin. The pulse duration tends to burn the cathode and cause blackening of the tube because they use a very low quality xenon flash tube. Theoretically a good quality xenon flash tube at 7ms pulse duration should be able to survive 50,000+ pulses, sometimes even up to 1,000,000 if it's a very good quality bulb. By good quality I mean a $4 bulb haha. Xenon flash tubes that small aren't exactly expensive. Remington really went out of their way to make sure you got a terrible product, I have no idea how they even managed to find such a horrible quality bulb. These bulbs do appear to be able to survive up to about 5000-6000 flashes from my experience thusfar before they simply explode or crack. Also, in Dr. Jay's patents he recommended between 5J/cm^2 to 40J/cm^2 of energy output to achieve satisfactory results, meaning for this system it is on the low end of that scale. He recommended 20J/cm^2 for people of coloured skin and the 40J/cm^2 for light skinned people. Those values would still only give temporary removal as well, it would not result in permanent follicle damage. Now.... after all that rambling, did it work? Yes it seems to have removed my hair. Some of it still grows but a good portion has been removed. Is it permanent? Well according to everything written about the technology it would appear to not be. IPL and laser themselves are not always permanent and given the low energy of this system it would suggest even more that it is not permanent. I'd recommend this if you have a small area that you want effectively kept hair free, I don't think I'd recommend it for legs or total body hair removal however, you would spend a fortune on bulb replacements. I gave it 3/5 because the price to quality just isn't there. You're paying a lot of money for what is essentially a glorified strobe light with a very poor quality and weak bulb that they slap a $5 700nm cutoff filter onto the front of and put it in a nice box. Then since they're so nice to you after you've handed them over $200 for the unit, they've developed a way to really grab your money with the low flash count on the bulbs which they charge a huge markup on. It's up to you whether you think this system is worth the price to replace waxing or shaving, you'll still need to shave much of the hair off since it can't get all of it of course. If you did your complete body and didn't mess around with the unit to unlock more flashes than I could easily see you using 5-6 bulbs/year, depending on how hairy you are I suppose. I had to flash every 2-4 days for the first month to see any real noticeable decrease in hair and I'm still flashing it about once a week and still need to shave many portions that this thing just can't seem to deal with despite the dark hair.
  314. Women .. this is it! Facial hair - GONE! The magic takes place with just 4 sessions! I bought it last year and it worked like magic on chin-hair. I had a few only but they were coarse and increasing & causing me untold UNEASE. Such freedom for $200 is priceless.   327. I was excited to use the Remington IPL device because I am, well, rather hairy and have sensitive skin. I was hoping to reduce my hair and have to shave less frequently, with smoother results. After a flash all I felt was a slight warmness and tingling for a few seconds. I had no blistering or irritation to my very sensitive skin later on. What was great is that I usually itch a lot after shaving, but with the treatment from the Remington IPL I have't itched at all. Today (Thursday) I went to use the device on my bikini line and after a few flashes, it quit working. The device was unlocked, the green light was on for the bulb and I pressed the flash button, but no flash happened. I called customer service and they recommended that I take the tip off and clean the window inside and out, but it was to no avail. I called customer service again and they are sending me a shipping label to send the device in for testing. OK so I edited this review to add that I tried cleaning the tip again, and plugging it into a different outlet, and it works again! No need to send it in for testing. I'm already seeing some slight results from the first treatment. I will update this review again when I have been using it for longer and can speak to the long term results. 2-MONTH UPDATE I have been using the device on level 5 on my bikini area every other week faithfully for the past two months. The hair is finer and softer, and there is slightly less of it. I would say it is about a 30% reduction in hair. It's nothing miraculous, but I find it easier to shave now. I will continue to treat every two weeks. I wish I had more drastic results, but I know I need to be patient.

  330. For the last ten years, I have been an adult woman struggling with unwanted facial hair. I am mixed race with light skin, but the hairs on my chin and throat are thick, wiry, and black. A decade ago, it was just a few hairs, but as of five years ago, it was enough that I had to switch to shaving, partly to save time, and partly to reduce the number of ingrown hairs that would result. These ingrown hairs have to be dug out in order to be removed, and have caused many blemishes. Furthermore, it's painful and embarrassing. I try to avoid well-lit places, I keep my head down even when I laugh, and I won't let myself be seen without makeup. I even tried to avoid having anyone touch my face for fear they would feel my bristly five o'clock shadow. I have despaired over this, felt helpless, powerless, and miserable over it. I have felt constantly ashamed at having to shave my face like a man. Honestly, it made me feel like less of woman and my self-esteem (never amazing to begin with) has suffered.<br /><br />I could never afford laser treatments at the salon, and I had heard that some mixed race skin tones were too dark, anyway. When I first heard about it, I considered NoNo, but only until I read the terrible reviews. Finally, a commercial for the Tria home laser changed my life (bear with me here, I know this is a review for the Remington). I never dreamed that something at home could work for me or my skin/hair type, but I did my research anyway. The reviews for the Tria were good, mostly, but more than a few people mentioned the Remington Pro IPL, and that it worked as well if not better, was less expensive, and had been on the market for a few years. I pored over the reviews (thank you TheRealWoman!!!), and despite the fact that the product is not recommended for the face, many, many customers confessed to using it there with amazing results. Just like that, I went from feeling like I had a guilty secret to hide from the world, to feeling like I was part of a community; on top of that, while I didn't want to build up my hopes too much, I dreamed of being close to a solution to what I had dubbed The Nightmare of My Life.<br /><br />I have used the Remington on my freshly shaven face, on the Level 3 setting, every other day for a month now. In order to really gauge light bulb life, I have used it exclusively on my primary problem areas, my chin and neck and (slight) mustache. I have also taken advice from other reviewers: I clean the laser window frequently, and give it 3-4 seconds in-between pulses to keep the bulb from overheating. I don't know if it helps, but it makes sense. Each session is approximately 40-50 pulses and takes me approximately 15 minutes, and so far I am still using the original bulb.<br /><br />At first I didn't detect any changes, but now, in my fourth week, I can see major progress. I don't need to do my mustache area anymore. To be fair, it was never plentiful or thick, but now you can no longer see the hair follicles or any growth. I am going to stop treating it and see if/when it grows back. Now my neck and chin...other reviewers reported noticeable results at two weeks. After four weeks, I can feel and see the difference. In the morning, before I shave, I feel fewer hairs. I still shave every day because I still have growth, but I believe this has a lot to do with growth cycles. I have had many ingrown hairs that I had to tweeze even while the majority were shaved off, so my growth cycle is currently all over the map. While I still do the whole area, it's starting to become apparent that hair is only growing noticeably in patches, mostly in the same places where I had frequent ingrown hairs.<br /><br />I cannot describe how incredible these results feel. If you've struggled with facial hair as a woman, you know how much it undermines your confidence, your enjoyment of life, your spontaneity. I feel like I can go camping again! Better yet, I feel like I can wake up next to someone and not run for the bathroom and the razor. I'm getting my life back and it feels absolutely amazing. (One more word about the price tag: If you're considering buying this, do it. I know I didn't mention it, but the price really scared me off, even though it was considerably cheaper than the Tria. But when I thought about what I would pay to be free of this nightmare, what I would pay for this to work, I realized the amount is a pittance. So far, I'm over the moon. If it continues like this/gets better, then that's the bee's knees. I can't believe I didn't buy this sooner! And if you're still reading this novel, do yourself a favor and be free, too. What's two hundy, really, in the grand scheme of your happiness?)my life back and it feels absolutely amazing. (One more word about the price tag: If you're considering buying this, do it. I know I didn't mention it, but the price really scared me off, even though it was considerably cheaper than the Tria. But when I thought about what I would pay to be free of this nightmare, what I would pay for this to work, I realized the amount is a pittance. So far, I'm over the moon. If it continues like this/gets better, then that's the bee's knees. I can't believe I didn't buy this sooner! And if you're still reading this novel, do yourself a favor and be free, too. What's two hundy, really, in the grand scheme of your happiness?)

After 2 months of treatments there is almost no hair and my legs look smooth and nice. The light that removes the hair on the highest setting feel like split second of a small rubber band snapping on the skin. I also don't have very sensitive skin.
  336. 10/16/16 EDIT: This worked GREAT when I first starting using it roughly 5 years ago before I became pregnant with my 1st born. I was only able to use it for a few months then I became pregnant so I stopped using it. Because I was too busy after my child was born I stopped using it. I recently (within the past 6 months) have used it a few times because I wanted to start back up and it died. It just won't work. I am very bummed because overall (even though there was a 4 year gap in between), I barely got 6 months to 1 year's worth of use but the warranty is over because it is a 2 year warranty. I changed my star to 1. Very disappointed because the product works well on hair removal but the product itself died with minimal usage. BUMMED OUT. Original Review: Ok first I am a little annoyed that I purchased this only 2 weeks ago for $50 more than it is now offered. But oh well. I am a former Tria owner (overall not impressed!) and the frustration with the Tria and its tiny laser head and short battery life led me to purchase this unit which doesn't need to be charged and has a bigger laser head. The downside of this unit is that you have to purchase refills for $25/each. I used 1 1/2 cartridges for 1 treatment session for my full legs. So I'm thinking after spending $250 on the product, and about 5 cartridges I will have spent for the full 3 treatments $375 to just do my legs...but that's still cheaper than professional laser services for your legs. I do think it also comes with a 90 day guarantee although I have to check the fine print again. I will try to return it within that time frame if I don't see results. You also need to read the fine print when it advertises that the cartridge is enough for 3 sessions of body (it is counting your body as lower legs, forearms, and bikini areas I think). So yeah that would make sense, but seeing that there is a lot of surface area for your FULL legs expect to use a little more than 1 cartridge each time. And Idon't have that much surface area on my legs compared to others as my legs are thin, although I am 5'6&#34; so perhaps if I was shorter it wouldn't take as many cartridges. I've done my legs twice and I'm not sure yet if I'm seeing a difference. I think I might be, but I really can't tell yet. I am the perfect candidate for laser (light skin, dark/thick hair) and have done professional laser hair removal in the past. Also, please remember that even professional laser hair removal isn't permanent :( unfortunately. I can tell you that all of the areas I've done professionally have grown back in to some degree. Anyways, seeing as it takes 2 weeks sometimes for hair to fall out, it is way too soon to tell if this works seeing as it has only been 1 week after my 2nd leg session. I do love the convenience of this product in that you don't have to wait around for it to recharge. The laser head is so much bigger than the Tria too. It is painful, why would anyone think it wouldn't be. But it is tolerable. Although I have done waxing, professional laser hair removal, electrolysis, you name it, so my pain tolerance has increased quite a bit. I will give an update when enough time has passed for me to know if this has worked. PS the light is VERY bright - I close my eyes or look away when it pulses as it honestly does feel like it is going to hurt my eyes even if it says it is not. It scared the crap out of one of my cats!
  337. I purchased this through Groupon back in December. I have only done a few treatments on my lower legs and underarms, at the highest setting. I have gone through 2 cartridges. After the last cartridge burned out in February, I put the machine away. The cartridges did not last as long as indicated. I only got 2 treatments from each cartridge. I could easily go through 1-2 a month at this rate. At $25 each, that's a lot a money! Plus, I have to shave with this machine. I feel waxing & epilating give better, longer lasting results.   338. I bought the Remington IPL6000 I Light Pro after seven sessions with an IPL method, in a private, certified salon.<br /><br />The flashes feel more comfortable than the one I tried in the saloon and it's way cheaper. These are, from my point of view, the two differences between the proffesional method and this DIY method.<br />The instructional video is quite good and it's better to watch it before getting started.<br /><br />I already had fewer hair when I started but my goal is accomplished: I wanted something to do the maintenance, and this one works great!
  339. I bought this 9 weeks ago, and have used it roughly every 10-12 days (admittedly, a little more frequently than the once every two weeks the package recommends), with the goal of getting rid of all of the hair on my chest and abdomen, just for fun. I wanted to be able to feel my wife skin-on-skin without all of my hair in the way. I have pale skin, and black hair; basically the ideal skin/hair combo for this product, so beware that if your skin is darker or your hair is lighter, you may either have more pain, or less results.<br /><br />Each treatment takes about 45 min to 1 hour, if you include the time to shower/shave first, zap zap zap everywhere, and then rinse off in the shower to be rid of the slight smell of burnt hair.<br /><br />The zapping itself is not bad. I use level five (the highest) all the time. This is about one-tenth of the pain of epilation (I've tried an epilator a few times, and I always quit after a few square inches, because the pain is much too intense). The description of a rubber band flicking the skin somewhat fits, but there is definitely some brief feeling of heat as well. If you've ever had wax dripped onto you, each time you press the button feels like that sensation, but only for a very brief split second, and then the pain is gone.<br /><br />The treatment window is narrow, and it is a bit hard to tell what you've already zapped sometimes. Fortunately, it does seem to cause a mild redness around the follicle (which has lasted up to two days) so that helps to see where you've zapped. But I definitely do miss spots.<br /><br />I am on my second (first replacement) bulb. Interestingly, the directions say the bulb maintains at least 90% of its intensity for the full 1500 flashes, but in fact, I found that when I changed bulbs, there was a dark appearance to half of the bulb I took out, as if it had been partially burned out, and the new replacement bulb was much stronger than the bulb I had just replaced. If you are spending this sort of money, I recommend always keeping a back-up bulb handy, in case your bulb has some unexpected problems. It seems from the other reviews like that is pretty common.<br /><br />Anyhow, I didn't really notice much results until about 7-10 days after my second session. Then, it was obvious that this thing was working. Nine weeks in, I'd say 70-80% of my hair is either completely gone or so fine as to be irrelevant, and I started out with coarse hair and a lot of it. I usually shave twice a week now, just to clean up the leftover hairs a bit, but even if I go a week without shaving, the hair is fine enough that it is not unpleasant. Shaving used to be unpleasant when so much coarse hair would start to grow back, but now, it is not a bother at all.<br /><br />I don't know how long the results are going to last, but I do know that this is less painful than epilation or waxing, and probably at least as durable. And cheaper than laser by a good bit. So no, it isn't perfect, but for light skin and dark hair, it is definitely the best option out there, and it has been well worth the purchase price in terms of the fun it has been to have a hairless front. If this product wasn't out there, I'd just choose to be hairy.
  340. I've gotten professional laser hair removal about 5 years ago. I started noticing the hair coming back. Although it was sparse, I thought I'd give this a try and save lot's of money. After reading the reviews, I bought it. I am SO happy I did. I have black hair and olive skin, and since I haven't been in the sun, my skin's light enough to use this product. Love the skin tone indicator, so you won't burn yourself :)<br /><br />Two weeks after the first treatment, the hairs on my legs are falling out. Compared to the pain of professional treatments being a 10, the pain scale of this laser on the highest setting is about a 6. I can see the area's I missed, and it'll be easy to go over them and be silky smooth in another two weeks. Awesome on the bikini line! Awesome on underarms! Awesome on my belly (yeah, pretty hairy lol) but if you're like me, PLEASE GIVE IT A TRY! It sounds silly, but it really makes a HUGE difference in day to day life.<br /><br />It's been two months now and I have 1 little spot left on my knee that I just zapped before I wrote this review...so give me two weeks and I'll be hair free!<br /><br />BUY it and ENJOY!!!

  344. I am the perfect candidate for IPL: light skin with dark hair, so I kept going thinking I would \\"get used to it.\\" WRONG! Although waxing hurts, this is way worse. It was even worse than getting a tattoo removed. If I was someone who cried a lot, there would have been tears. Instead, my kids learned some \\"colorful\\" new words from their mother. Save your money and look for deals at local laser hair removal clinics. A ND:YAG, or Diode laser doesn't hurt half as bad and the light is more focused/direct, so the treatment works better. I've had professional laser hair removal on my face and it worked great. Then I thought I could save money by doing the rest of my body with this device. Bad IDEA!
  345. I am pretty fair-skinned, so I was fairly confident this would work for me.   353. I'm a man with pretty dark thick hair and if it works for me I'm pretty sure it will work for anyone, but it will probably take longer than advertised.<br />First of all, don't buy the protective goggles as they are not necessary. The light is safe and it says so on the manual. I don't think the anesthetic creams are necessary either. I have pretty sensitive skin and the \\"pain\\" is perfectly tolerable.<br />I'm using it for almost everything: chest, neck, back of my head, back, beard and arms. It is important to say that they don't suggest to use it on the neck and above.<br />The most important thing you should know is that the thicker the hair the longer it will take to work and the hair won't die at first. It will get thinner and thinner until it disappears. But this can take more than 10 applications depending on the thickness of the hair and the hair density of the area. For example: I have used twice in my arm pit and there is less hair and they are thinner than before. I have used 5 times on my beard and the change is minimum.   362. OK, first, I am a freak about having smooth legs. I used to shave every day, including the days I gave birth. It's possible I was a bit compulsive about it. So I picked up the iLight home hair-removal system with high hopes for kicking the shaving habit. Six months after first use, my legs are hairless and have been for more than a month. Hurray!<br /><br />USE: In short, you shave your legs and then dry them. Right after shaving, you hold the hand-held zapper against your leg, a chime sounds if you have good contact, you push a button, and a light flashes. Repeat everywhere you want to remove hair. It takes longer than shaving, but it's not bad (maybe 20 minutes for both legs), and you can do it on the couch, in bed, wherever. It does not hurt, at all, but it does feel warm where the contacts touch your skin.<br /><br />MY EXPERIENCE: I did my right leg first, so as to compare. Following the directions, I did treatment one, then treatment two 2 weeks later, and treatment three 2 weeks after that (completing 3 treatments in a month). After that first month I noticed a lot less regrowth, and started the cycle on my left leg. After the first 3 treatments on each leg I started using it on an as-needed basis, which I needed with decreasing frequency. And now, I haven't shaved or used the iLight for about a month. Hurray!<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE: Follow the directions, have patience, and you will soon be tossing your razors. (NOTE: Suitable only for light to medium skin tones.)

  364. I think this is a very, very difficult item to review. Everyone's experience with it will vary; it will NOT produce the same results for everyone. Would be great if it did, but that's just not the case. I find that reading ALL instructions are important and knowing the devices limitations are key, too. Nothing on the planet promises PERMANENT HAIR REMOVAL except for traditional needle-in-each-pore electrolysis. Laser, or IPL can at best promise PERMANENT HAIR REDUCTION and that's only if 1) you have the right skin type, 2) you have dark enough hair and 3) you manage to hit the hair during the right growth cycle in order to \\"damage\\" it. Tip: read about the three phases of hair growth to understand why you have to \\"zap\\" it in the ANAGEN growth phase.<br /><br />I've had a facial hair problem since my teens and I've tried everything on the market from bleach (imagine being told from a boy in middle school that your bleached-blonde moustache makes you look like Hulk Hogan), to hair removal cream, to electrolysis, to laser, to plucking and finally, in my 30s, I just starting shaving it because it was easy and cheap. I long ago lost any hint of shame in being a woman who shaves her face.<br /><br />So, I've tried it all. Electrolysis worked, but was extremely painful and left me with pitting and scars. IPL/laser worked, to some degree, but is very cost prohibitive and most places want to sign you up for some complex package that is priced depending on what day of the week it is. Plucking works, but it's a weekly thing and I had SO many hairs that it took forever. The creams burned and smelled. Bleach? Yeah, no.<br /><br />I was so excited to see this device on the market for a fraction of what I was about to pay (again) for five treatments at a local clinic ($800 - $1100 for treating my face and upper neck). I figured for $250, I'd take that gamble. Yes, I knew it wouldn't be as powerful, but I would have complete control and I liked that. A lot.<br /><br />I should note here that I'm 36, female, medium-skinned, brown hair and have dark stubble. Though this device is NOT cleared for face or neck, that's what I'm using it for. I didn't know this until I was reading the brochure. So, there's that. I am treating my upper lip, chin, cheeks and upper neck. I just close my eyes when the device flashes and keep it away from my eyes.<br /><br />I've been using the device for about three and a half months now, about every 10 days (which is more than recommended). I have it cranked up to max settings. The pain level, for me, is very tolerable. I think that's because I've had so much done to my face over the years. Even at max settings, I don't even flinch using this device. The first time I used it, I was completely red and blotchy. I applied some lidocream and was good to go in about an hour. After treatment two, I have no real redness or blotchyness. It's quite possible my skin is actually made of bologna.<br /><br />The device is extremely easy to use. I wish the sensor area was bigger though. Of course, that would make zapping some areas on my face hard, so...maybe not. And the \\"skin color detector\\" is oddly-placed; holding the device up to your inner thigh is going to be extremely awkward if that's the area you're treating. ;) I just place the back of my hand on it and \\"unlock\\" the device that way. Treating my face/chin/neck takes about 5 mins. I have had no issues with the device or the cartridge. I'd estimate I've put about 300 flashes on it so far.<br /><br />So, here's the tl;dr (\\"too long, didn't read): it works, to a point. I have less dark, thick hairs. I'm still shaving, but if I miss a few days, no biggie. I would even argue that some hairs have appears to stay on permanent vacation. At this point, I would say my overall hair situation on the treated areas is 65% better. And for $250, I'm happy with that.here that I'm 36, female, medium-skinned, brown hair and have dark stubble. Though this device is NOT cleared for face or neck, that's what I'm using it for. I didn't know this until I was reading the brochure. So, there's that. I am treating my upper lip, chin, cheeks and upper neck. I just close my eyes when the device flashes and keep it away from my eyes.<br /><br />I've been using the device for about three and a half months now, about every 10 days (which is more than recommended). I have it cranked up to max settings. The pain level, for me, is very tolerable. I think that's because I've had so much done to my face over the years. Even at max settings, I don't even flinch using this device. The first time I used it, I was completely red and blotchy. I applied some lidocream and was good to go in about an hour. After treatment two, I have no real redness or blotchyness. It's quite possible my skin is actually made of bologna.<br /><br />The device is extremely easy to use. I wish the sensor area was bigger though. Of course, that would make zapping some areas on my face hard, so...maybe not. And the \\"skin color detector\\" is oddly-placed; holding the device up to your inner thigh is going to be extremely awkward if that's the area you're treating. ;) I just place the back of my hand on it and \\"unlock\\" the device that way. Treating my face/chin/neck takes about 5 mins. I have had no issues with the device or the cartridge. I'd estimate I've put about 300 flashes on it so far.<br /><br />So, here's the tl;dr (\\"too long, didn't read): it works, to a point. I have less dark, thick hairs. I'm still shaving, but if I miss a few days, no biggie. I would even argue that some hairs have appears to stay on permanent vacation. At this point, I would say my overall hair situation on the treated areas is 65% better. And for $250, I'm happy with that.

  369. I am writing this review to prevent people from the same mistake I made. I have had laser hair removal on my armpits and bikini area and bought this hoping to get similar results on my legs. I bought this product for myself as a holiday present in Dec 2011. I followed the intructions exactly. I though it maybe was helping, and I was willing to repeat the process forever until the hair was gone. But since I have a scientific background, I decided to do casual experiment instead.<br /><br />So I treated my left leg only, and left my right leg alone, for six treatments. THen I counted the number of hairs within a 2x2 area on each leg. Now this was after the initial 6 week treatment on both legs, but I really could not tell if it was doing anything. Yes some hairs fell out, but did they come back? And will more fall out with more treatments? Well the short answer is after six more treatments, there was only a very slight difference between my left leg and my right leg. This product can not deliver the smooth skin shown on the models on the box. THe hair IS slightly less dense. But so what? I still have to shave just as often, had to buy THREE cartriges (they do not last nearly as long as stated), and now have this dumb machine taking up space in my home after wasting $250 on it.<br /><br />Also- disposal of the cartriges in an environmentaly responsible manner takes an extra effort. DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY

  371. I bought to use on chin hairs. Details on the item does not say not for use on the face.
  372. This product works, but it works very slowly and you're better off going for professional laser hair removal. My biggest complaint with this product is Remington's misrepresentation on the cartridge lifespan (which incurs high follow-up costs) and the terrible customer service. The cartridge is supposed to last 1,500 flashes per bulb, but my cartridge burned out after approx 400 flashes. When I contacted Amazon (whose service I have no complaints about), Amazon informed me that this is such a common problem that Remington has a phone service line dedicated for calls on such defects and gave me their number.<br /><br />When I called that number and described the issue to the lady on the line, not only was she extremely rude, but she said the only solution was for me to pay to mail the cartridge to Remington, and after a few weeks of \\"investigating\\", they may mail me a replacement if they find that it was a mechanical issue on their part. OK, first of all 1) Remington knows this is a widespread problem, so this is how they address a defective design on their part? 2) They want the consumer to pay and go through the hassle of shipping a defective cartridge back to them?<br /><br />If you're considering this because you think it'll be a convenient and cheaper alternative to professional laser hair removal, then don't purchase this system. Not only are the results temporary and spotty at best, but you'll be spending much more than the initial $200. The cartridges don't last as long as promised, and you'll need to buy $20 cartridges many times over. In the end, you'll mostly be losing your $ to Remington and not losing much hair.

Accordingly, I'm sure the reviews here and people's experiences will vary a lot. But it does work!!<br />____________________________________________________________<br />Update 2/8/2012: So, after a bunch of treatments (6?) I'm back to update. You are probably wondering how I fit so many treatments in in the ~7 weeks or so since my last update - I'll get to that.<br />The results: I *do* still have hair on my legs (the only place I've treated so far). HOWEVER: it is much more sparse and thin than it was before. I'm disappointed I wasn't TOTALLY! HAIRLESS! after 3 sessions as the advertisement promised, but I do think it's *working* and will continue to treat. The reason I'm not downgrading my rating to fewer stars (yet) is because:<br />1) For my first 3 treatments I was so excited about the device, I only waited 1 week between treatments. I read in the comment section here that professional IPL actually recommends you wait up to 4 weeks between treatments (!) because it takes 10-15 days just for the hairs to fall out. If they haven't fallen out, they haven't re-grown, so you're treating the same hairs over and over if it you do it too frequently. As soon as I read that, I switched to every 2 weeks like they recommend. My bad for not following directions initially and I do think this has affected my results.<br />2) My leg from knee to ankle is a *lot* of surface area; at least more so than places like tummyor underarms. I am pretty sure I have not yet mastered the art of not missing spots when I'm treating (most of my thicker remaining hair is centered on my shinbone for some reason - maybe I keep missing there?) so perhaps every hair has not been treated every time. My sister-in-law has this device as well and said it's working miracles for her everywhere but not as much on her legs. So that's a theory.<br /><br />I'm now working on bikini area and am going to keep treating my legs. I expect to see a significant reduction very very soon. If not, I'll be back to report. (This review will get impossibly long!)<br />____________________________________________________________________________________<br />Update 12/12/2011: My second treatment was this weekend and I can definitively say I have fewer hairs growing back today than I would normally. I last shaved on Thursday (today is Monday) and usually my legs would already be covered in noticeable stubble, so I think it's actually working. I'd post pictures here if I could! I have small patches of leg that have no hair, and the hairy patches (ick) are less.. thick.. dense?.. than they should be.<br /><br />One thing to know that is difficult about the device is the window is smaller than the treatment head, so it's hard to see what patches are overlapping and which aren't. I imagine this will make for initially patchy results, but it's easy to go back and spot treat. More updates to come.<br />__________________________________________________________________________________<br />I certainly hope the hair removal industry is ready, because they are going DOWN!<br /><br />Super excited to be an early-adopter of one of these devices because now I get to be totally hairless before all of my friends. Well, at least that's what I'm hoping. Full disclosure is that I just bought my i-light last week so have only done one treatment so far (second one scheduled for a few days from now), so I plan to review it today and then update again once I've done the full 3 treatments they recommend before seeing results.<br /><br />So far, I couldn't be happier with the machine. It's easy to use (after reading the instruction booklet, of course) and I'm pretty confident it will work (when I zapped areas of my leg that I missed while shaving, I actually saw the little hairs shriveling up). It IS important, as they say, to shave beforehand because a) it hurts less and b) no burnt hair smell. I was able to use power level 5 so hopefully after treatment #2 I'll start seeing fewer hairs.

  380. This review is from the husband. The very best thing about this device is when she lets me run it. You know, on her. It is rather a science fiction type of device and you almost cannot believe it will work at zapping hair, yet it is so much fun to use that, at first, it just doesn't matter if it does or not. Then after a few weeks go by and she begins to become an alabaster sculpture. Now I chose that analogy (metaphor?) correctly since you do not want to buy one of these if you are dark complected as it will cook you. Also, the smooth alabaster surface is just how she feels to the touch. It really does work.<br /><br />I did not keep track at how long we took before the initial lamp bulb expired, but I was not shocked when it died. The replacements are available on ebay and worth it for the effect this thing achieves. It has not eliminated all hair, but it has greatly reduced the texture of stiffness, or columnar strength of the hair, makes it grow much more slowly and sparsely and what does appear is lighter in shade. In fact we have used it less and less, and I think with more disciplined use, it would make her almost hair free.<br /><br />It has a cooling fan and is a bit noisy, about that of a nice quality electric shaver. The zapping itself is akin to a stretched rubber band snap and depending on how much you dial up the zapper and how sensitive you are varies in its intensity from mild to ZAP. Take it slow and keep after it and you will be pleased at the result. With the cost of good razor blades, this item may come closer to paying for itself than one might think.<br /><br />One draw back is that the sessions take a while as you have to cover ground slowly as the zapper only covers so much skin per zap. I think this Remington zaps as much surface area if not more than the Tria, et al, but it still takes a while.<br /><br />Notice that it does have a cord. It produces not a laser pulse of light, but a very high intensity flash. You will need to look to the side if you are running it on someone, or perhaps consider some light sunglasses.<br /><br />But, again, make the zapping session a team effort and it turns into one of those little games for the couple of intrigue.

  382. UPDATE: Saturday March 16th, 2013 TWELFTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 121 + 1304 from previous sessions. Total = 1425<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />*ORIGINAL* FLASH CARTRIDGE FINALLY DIED BUT!.......<br /><br />It could have gone longer. There is definitely a counter in the unit that does not go beyond 1500 flashes and seeing as how I'm within 75 flashes, that seems par for the course considering there were times I lost count (from the pain at times lol) and tried to pick up where I *thought* I was.<br /><br />I checked the bulb after the last session and aside from looking a little worn it seemed quite intact in every way. There were no cracks or signs of damage.<br /><br />Now if you think about it Remington probably tested the cartridge to its breaking point and let's say that after a few tests in a controlled environment, they realized that the bulb cracked or even exploded at say, 1800 pulses. As a result of the bulb cracking or exploding the unit itself was damaged. Maybe it melted a fan blade or messed up the electronics permanently. This may be what led to the unit using a counter to make sure that at a safe number like 1500, the unit would render the cartridge useless. So as much as Remington is making money off replacement cartridges, they are also providing an effective fail-safe to ensure that the unit isn't damaged and the user is satisfied to a degree.<br /><br />I don't like the fact that the cartridge could have lasted longer but I've seen how light bulbs can burn out, pop and explode and when I think of that happening next to some sensitive parts of my body???? I'd rather just pay for another cartridge. I'll keep reviewing the replacement cartridges on their product page but as for this product, yes, you guessed it. FIVE STARS!!!! *****<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Tuesday March 12th, 2013 ELEVENTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 75 + 1229 from previous sessions. Total = 1304<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />A FEW TOUCH UPS<br /><br />Did some additional light touch ups around my bikini line and waist above my navel and I just noticed that the bulb life indicator is now YELLOW (It has been GREEN up until now).... This is telling me that I'm extremely close to the bulbs death, FINALLY. Still though, the unit is still flashing on the original bulb and I'll let you all know at what number it finally dies. Can't wait to see the difference in intensity between the original bulb and a new one.<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Thursday March 7th, 2013 TENTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 310 + 919 from previous sessions. Total = 1229<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />GOING FOR BROKE!<br /><br />OK so now I'm starting to wonder if this flash bulb will ever die. I showered and shaved the entire area but this time I went a little further past the bikini line hence the lengthy session. No lotions or moisturizers were applied to the area prior to treatment. I flashed every part of my crotchal region from front to back, paused a minute or two every now and then to let the bulb cool and wiped the lens in between flashes. After treatment, I left the unit on so the fan would cool the bulb until it reset and then activated it again and left the fan to run a second time until reset. This way I know everything has cooled down before I put it back in the box. I have to say I'm starting to love the feel of it all and my wife loves it too :). So now, after all these treatments I can now go a day or two without feeling the need to shave and at this point I can probably go a few more days but the OCD in me keeps making me shave lol.<br /><br />We are now at 1169 flashes on the original bulb so I don't see any reason to dock any stars on my review.... I am MUCH MUCH smoother than before and I can now shaveagainst the grain of hair without a single ugly red ingrown hair showing up. THE ONLY THING THAT I FIND ANNOYING ABOUT THIS PRODUCT IS; the button is very elusive when you are bending and twisting your wrist to get at those hard to reach spots. The fix for this is simple. Put a little nub on the center of the button so when your flashing and you can't see the button, you can feel for the center and press it properly.<br /><br />Excellent product!<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Thursday Feb 28th, 2013 NINTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 184 + 735 from previous sessions. Total = 919<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />Same prep for session as last time and same routine. I shaved, dried the area thoroughly, DID NOT APPLY ANY CREAMS OR LOTIONS TO THE AREA, flashed every part of my crotchal region from front to back, paused a minute or two every now and then to let the bulb cool and wiped the lens in between flashes. This unit is still running strong on the original flash cartridge at 919 flashes and that's after over 2 months of weekly use! Now you should all know that I am breaking some of the rulese here. I'm using this device every 7 to 10 days as opposed to the recommended 2 week wait. I'm also doing FULL sessions every session instead of \\"touch ups\\" like the instructions recommend.<br /><br />So far I'm about 80 percent hairless in the crotch front to back with the regrowth being a little thinner. Total = 735<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />Same prep for session as last time and same routine. I shaved, dried the area thoroughly, flashed every part of my crotchal region from front to back, paused a minute or two every now and then to let the bulb cool and wiped the lens in between flashes. One thing I am definitely noticing is that, as the sessions progress they are slowly getting shorter... I'm still doing every inch of my pubic area but I'm flashing a larger area as in, that after a flash I'm placing the gun a little farther away from the last area flashed. It's not because I'm trying to be frugal with the bulb or anything, it's just because I'm seeing less and less hair and it's getting harder to tell where there is and isn't hair which is a great sign that the product is working. Another thing I'm noticing which I LOVE is NO MORE INGROWN HAIRS!!!!!! I'm now shaving against the grain in areas where shaving against would mean painful ingrown hairs and red spots. Amazing! No other product EVER, has been able to do this.<br /><br />So after all the reviews on amazon saying that the cartridge does not last I honestly think its because of either factor<br /><br />A) The unit is not being used with care.<br />B) It's defective.<br />C) The unit is not being maintained properly.<br /><br />You HAVE TO:<br />- Clean the lens after a few flashes<br />- Take your time and resist flashing it like a paparazzi<br />- Let the gun cool for 2 resets when your done.<br />- Put it back in the original box when it has cooled properly to keep dust and dirt out of the system.<br /><br />That's all I'm doing and I made it past the 700 flash mark. Hopefully we'll be able to go further.<br /><br />5 stars remain.......
