We'll have to wait and see.<br /><br />As for the results...Well I looked under my ball sack earlier today and I noticed that there was absolutely no trace of hair to be seen, not even black spots. The same goes for the bikini line. The area above my penis is hit and miss but I'm starting to see the bald patches growing in size so I'm sure that in time it will look like my bikini line. As for my ass crack, well, I really can't see back there and I'm not gonna start using a mirror or anything but it does feel smoother even after I haven't shaved for a full 24 hours. Usually it starts getting itchy after that much time has gone by.<br /><br /> I believe this product does EXACTLY what Remington has stated it will do and nothing more. To me it's obvious that they did test it extensively so that they could manage our expectations accurately. The only area where I can see improvement is in the false claim that it will last 1500 pulses as these results were no doubt, obtained under very strict controlled conditions so there should be some mention of this in the manual as well as a notice that not everyone will get the same life span out of the cartridge. Either way, to Remington I say bravo for making a great product. To me this is well worth the money.<br /><br />5 stars remain....... For now<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Monday Jan 28th, 2013 SIXTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 142 + 369 from previous sessions. Total = 511<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />Well the bulb is still going strong andI'd like to hear form people who's bulb did not make it past 500 flashes. To those people I'm pretty sure you are working the bulb too hard i.e. too many flashes per minute, not pausing enough in between flashes, not cleaning the lens and not letting the gun cool and \\"automatically shut off\\" or \\"reset\\" after your session. This is all I'm doing and so far it is keeping the bulb intact and functioning as it should. Another thing I've discovered is that the instructions tell you to shave the area and wipe the skin clean and completely dry the area... This is EXTREMELY important!!! If you shave then apply some sort of moisturizer to the skin, yes your skin is clean but the oils from the moisturizer will leave a residue on the leans during the sessions thereby making the gun retain more heat than it can bleed off, and if you're not constantly cleaning the lens then don't be surprised when the cartridge prematurely dies on you.<br /><br />Still doing the pubic area from front to back and still using my yoga skills to their limits lol..... As for results, I could not be happier. There seems to be more bald patches and in the areas where the hair is still growing back it is coming in thinner and finer. Great results after just 6 weeks of treatments. the 5 stars REMAIN!.. For now.<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Thursday Jan 18th, 2013 FIFTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 127 + 242 from previous sessions. Total = 369<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />OK so I have officially been at this for an entire month and here is my verdict.... This product works AS PROMISED and I really do mean that. If you have a look in the manufacturers description it says that that it will \\"deliver results that last 6 months\\" and you'll notice that right next to it is an asterisk.... Here is what this little asterisk means \\"*Individual results will vary. In clinical testing, on average, participants had 47.8 percent fewer hairs six months after just three treatments, similar to results observed from professional hair removal systems.\\" AND THEY ARE RIGHT!<br /><br />In the past month and after 5 full treatments I am noticing around 45 percent hair loss. will it last 6 months? I don't really think so but that varies from one person to another. Furthermore, I did not use it as directed. Near the end I was using it once a week instead of the recommended 2 weeks. Also, they have been full treatments and not the recommended touch ups after the first three treatments. All in all, I am still NOT disappointed with the I-light Pro. It promises reduced hair growth and I got that. It promises slower regrowth and I got that too. It promised 1500 flashes on the light cartridge and mine is still going strong so I can't really comment on it yet but we will see. Would I buy this item again? YES. Should you? Yes IF you have the right skin/hair combination but again, DON'T EXPECT MIRACLES. Expect it to help you in your hair removal process and keep you from spending stupid insane amounts of money going to laser clinics and spas to have something done for you that you can do for yourself for MUCH LESS MONEY.<br /><br />would I have liked the I-light Pro to give better results? Of course but hey, I read all the reviews and I know what I bought into. Furthermore, I don;t have the Ideal Skin, hair combination. Yes I am fair skinned and yes I have dark brown/black hair but I do have some grey hair starting to pop up here and there so I can;t really expect it to work as promised... And since long term results literally take YEARS to achieve, I'll keep at it. To be honest it's kind of fun to use ;)<br /><br />I will keep updating this review until I have to switch the light cartridge but so far, so good......<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Thursday Jan 10th, 2013 FOURTH SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 74 + 168 from previous sessions. Total = 242<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />NEED TO TAKE CONTORTION LESSONS TO GET BACK THERE.<br /><br />I must be addicted to this product because I just did a full treatment AGAIN! The only reason I did it is because I'm really noticing a difference in the rate of hair growth and the regrowth. Also, there was another review here where the reviewer was using it every few days and she was getting amazing results so why not try it right?<br /><br />This time around I did front AND back and by back I mean I really had to reach down between my legs and spread areas that I never EVER though I'd be spreading. Since I am used to shaving my but crack and around my butt hole by feel in the shower, I did the same with the I-Light Pro. It was much harder than I thought. The thick \\"cable\\" made it hard to get the head into the right position to zap so if there is one thing I'd recommend to Remington, it's to make it all just a wee bit more versatile in this sense WITHOUT making it cordless. Either way, the job got done regardless of all the bending, twisting and spreading.<br /><br />As usual, I checked the lens every second or third flash to make sure that it stayed clean. If there was any dust or dirt, I quickly cleaned the lens to make sure everything was running smooth. So far this little sucker is going strong with 242 flashes under it's belt.<br /><br />Still impressed, still 5 stars.<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />QUICK UPDATE: Wednesday Jan 9, 2013 OBSERVATIONS (no session performed)<br />Flashes used this session = 0 + 168 from previous sessions. Total = 168<br /><br />It's been 3 days since my last session and here is what I am noticing.<br /><br />- Reduced hair growth and *delayed* hair growth int he area I have been treating (bikini line, ball sack, perineum, area around anus pubic hair all around penis.<br />- Bald patches in some areas as in NO TRACE OF HAIR :)<br />- Hair growing in thinner and sparser.<br />- No redness or irritated skin like you'd get epilating.<br />- No indication of Bulb \\"konking out\\" and on that note, read on.<br /><br />I will ding Remington for making such a false claim that the bulb will last 1500 flashes BUT, you all have to know that when they tested the bulb life, they wanted to get the most flashes so how did they achieve this? Here's how:<br /><br />- They used it on the lowest setting<br />- They allowed the flash cartridge to properly cool between flashes (as in, not flash constantly for minutes on end like some people who are in a rush may do)<br />- They tested it in a properly ventilated room to prevent premature overheating.<br />- They tested it under PERFECTLY CLEAN AND DUST FREE CONDITIONS.<br />- The flash bulb test was NOT done while being used on someone's skin hence the lens was never dirty during the test and which did not lead to added heat building up in the unit (The lens DOES get dirty very quickly even after 5 or 6 flashes).<br /><br />So doing it like this, I can see how Remington's test facility got 1500 flashes out of the cartridge. Now then; Here is why I think the cartridges aren't lasting 1500 flashes.<br /><br />- People are using it on the highest setting all the time (obviously it's gonna impact the life of the flash bulb no matter what people here will tell you)<br />- People are using it in a poorly kept environment i.e. dusty room from pet dander, pet hair, smoking (dust accumulates on the lens and bulb itself and negatively impact its lifespan)<br />- People are using it in a hot/humid room<br />- People are NOT keeping the lens clean during treatment sessions and in between flashes.<br /><br />So folks, when you use it, make time for the session so that you're not in a rush. Do the treatment in a clean, cool and dust free environment. Give the device time to cool properly in between flashes (thisties back to the whole *take your time* thing), keep the lens clean during your sessions and in between flashes and don't use it immediately after a shower/bath in your bathroom (heat).<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Sunday Jan 6, 2013 THIRD SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 60 + 108 from previous sessions. Total = 168<br />Setting : 5<br /><br />GOING FOR THE BURN!<br /><br />OK so it's only been 4 days since the last session and not 2 weeks like the instructions recommend. WHY? Well, I was talking to my wife about the treatments and mentioned that I wasn't really smelling any burnt hair to which she replied, \\"Then it may not be working... Are you using it on it's highest setting?\\" to which I replied, \\"No, I'm using it on level 4 which is one notch down from the highest, level 5\\". So she said, \\"Do it again on the highest setting. You should be smelling burnt hair.\\" therefore, I'm considering this treatment more of a touch up than a session.<br /><br />That said, I have to say that I'm seeing results even before the third treatment. I'm starting to see actual BALD SPOTS which is encouraging considering that I have only done 2 sessions. The third went just as well as the second. In terms of pain, there isn't much of a difference between level 4 and 5 but I did smell a bit more burnt hair which was the overall goal. I later treated the area with some Aloe Vera but so far, my skin is reacting quite well. There's no blistering or crazy redness. Had I tried epilating in the same spot, it would have hurt like hell and created tons of red spots and irritated the skin. I am really starting to like this product.<br /><br />Now.... In between treatments, I've been researching other IPL products and found that they are all doing the same thing but instead of using the more common term \\"IPL\\" (Intense Pulse Light) some are using a new term called \\"HPL\\" or \\"Home PulseLight\\"... Don't let this new term fool you, THERE IS NO DIFFERENCE. Also, in my research I was looking at the Silk'n SN-008 Flash&Go which sells here on Amazon for 299.00.... Overall the device does EXACTLY the same thing that the I-Light Pro does but with a few unnecessary extras. I don't think it's an inferior product but I do think that it's no better than the I-Light Pro. I also came across a YouTube video about the Silk'n SN-008 Flash&Go and the video specifically states that \\"due to the nature of the hair growth cycle, achieving long term results may require multiple treatment sessions over a period of 18-24 months\\". They mention it at 07:27 in this video [...] Taking this into consideration, you can expect the same thing with the I-light Pro....<br /><br />So after 14 days and only 2 sessions I'm seeing good results therefore the review will remain at 5 stars. More to come...<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />UPDATE: Jan 2nd, 2013 SECOND SESSION<br />Flashes used this session = 68 + 40 from last session. Total = 108<br />Setting : 4<br /><br />NOTE: I decided to wait the full 2 weeks like the instructions recommend.<br /><br />First the prep. I shaved my groin area and dried it thoroughly. Then flashed the area from the perineum (gap between your butthole and your vagina/ball sack) to my navel and it wasn't that bad this time around. The one thing I did that made a difference is; anytime the flashes started to hurt even a bit, I'd flash, wait until the pain from the last flash would subside (about 20 seconds) then flash the next section. It really did make it more comfortable for me. I'm not noticing any REAL hair loss yet as it is only my second session and there are many IPL pros here who say it takes many months before seeing NOTICEABLE results, so for now the review remains at 5 stars.<br /><br />***QUICK TIP TO ENSURE PROPER BULB LIFE: Try to remember to wipethe lens thoroughly BETWEEN flashes. This keeps the lens clean and thereby makes the treatment more effective not to mention allows more of the light to pass THROUGH the lens so that the heat from the flash doesn't get bounced back into the cartridge adding to the heat build up. Also, once you are done DO NOT TURN OFF THE UNIT!!!! Let the fan run until the unit shuts itself off and you hear a beep, then feel the exhausted air coming out of the base and make sure it is COOL before turning the unit off. There, you've just eliminated another variable that MAY kill the flash bulb sooner. More to come...<br /><br />HAPPY ZAPPING :)<br /><br />BTW, to bide my time I've been reading reviews from other similar products but one product that REALLY caught my attention was the NO-NO... As in \\"NO-NO the freikin thing broke down again!!!\\" Lol. This ridiculous POS sells for as high as 350.00 and is nowhere near as reliable or as effective as the I-light pro. While the I-light Pro sells for as little as 180 (with coupon if you're lucky enough to find one). I pity those who regretfully gave the NO-NO a chance. Now their money is NO-NOwhere to be found. Lol<br /><br />---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />Sunday December 23rd, 2012 FIRST SESSION<br />Setting : 1-3<br /><br />First of all, let me just say that I'm in my early forties and starting to get gray hair on my head and I'm not expecting miracles like some other reviewers. I read all the reviews and all I expect this product to do is prevent hair from growing back so quickly that I need to shave every day. I am a guy and I HATE hair. It's ugly and having been a cyclist for so long, I learned to shave EVERYTHING, from front to back and legs as well. I love the feeling and so does my wife. what I don't like is all the prep work and process to be hairless. Also, when biking, the grinding of the legs really makes it hard on my thighs and crotch so Ineed to be hairless down there.<br /><br />Anyways, on with my review. I bought the Remington I-light PRO from Amazon and picked it up a few days ago. As soon as I got it home I opened it and began reading the instructions. Much to my delight Remington seems to manage customer expectations VERY WELL. The instructions DO mention that the unit will not work as expected when used on dark skin and white/gray or blonde hair. Also it mentions that it is dangerous to use if you have dark skin so I really don't understand why people are giving it one star ratings when they didn't either follow the instructions or have the right combination of skin/hair. The instructions also recommend cleaning the lens and unit before putting it away after every session. Now, to be completely fair, the instructions DON'T tell you to leave the unit on after use so that the fan can cool the bulb which I'm guessing is leading to so many light cartridges not getting anywhere near 1500 flashes Which I can live with... Hell the bulbs are 20 dollars EACH and when compared to a professional laser hair removal session which I'm hearing can cost upwards of 200 EACH SESSION, the I light PRO really isn't that costly,<br /><br />So I used it on my crotch area and it does seem to work. Shaving prior to treatment is key as this product is designed to work below the skin BUT BE ADVISED, shave IN THE DIRECTION OF HAIRS AND NOT AGAINST!!! shaving against will get you a closer shave yes, but you'll have to deal with ingrown hairs no matter how much exfoliating and moistirizing you do. Shave your legs anyway you want but for the bikini line and crotch area and for the purpose of preparing the skin for THIS type of treatment and future treatments, the last thing you want is red bumps and ingrowns. The flashes not only kill the hair but also burn the extra hair right off and like many reviewers said, it does feel like a rubber band being snapped on your skin. I tried it on level 4 and found that the pain was quite manageable but I have yet to try it on level 5. Once it was over I had treated my groin area making sure not to overlap flashes and it left my skin feeling rough because the burnt hair is still there but we'll see what happens in the next few days. I'm gonna try using it once a week depending on whether or not there will be red bumps, itchiness or irritated skin. If there is any of this, I'll use it every 2 weeks as per the instructions. Let's see how it goes. More to come in my update :)<br />P.S. Total flashes used so far = 40
  383. I have had my Remington ipl for almost a year now so I figure this is a good time to give an experienced review.<br /><br />Let me start by saying that if you are going to buy this product you need to be realistic about the results you are going to get. Don't forget that this is an AT HOME laser so you will not get the same results you would in the salon. With that being said, this laser works well. I have tan skin and very dark hair on my body, I've used the product on my lower legs, underarms and bikini so far. In the beginning I used the laser faithfully every three weeks. Within 4 treatments I noticed significantly less hair on the treated areas. Within 3 months I'd say 50% less on my legs, 50% less under my arms and about 80% less on the bikini line. I was pleasantly surprised with the bikini line results because that was the area I wanted to treat the most.<br /><br />Lately I've been using my laser a lot less, maybe once a month. Mainly because I just got lazy with it, and it can be painful (it feels like a hot rubber band snap). The darker and thicker the hair, the more you will feel it. As summer draws closer I plan on using my laser more frequently. I would like to do my thighs next. The bottom line is, this laser has already payed for itself. Like I said you will not get professional results but if you have the right hair, you WILL see a decrease in hair.
  384. I have been using this on my chest for about 4 months now. It is quite easy to use, and after the first or second time, the small \\"tinge\\" you get with each flash becomes tolerable at the highest setting (5). It does not take long to do my entire chest, maybe 5-10 minutes at most. I have been using this every two weeks for the first 3 months as was suggested by the directions. this pas tmonth I have used it every week, to see if it would increase the results. So far, this has removed about 50-60% of the hair on my chest, and the remainder hair grows in slower. It used to have to shave it at least once every 6-7 days. Now, it takes about 2 weeks for the hair to grow the same length it would previously in 6-7 days. I am white, and have fair skin in the winter, and tan easily in the summer. I have not had any issues with this product due to skin color or tan. Although, I must mention, that in order to \\"unlock\\" the product (each time u turn it on), you must put the sensor close to your skin so it can detect and make sure your skin is the correct color. Sometimes, it seems this sensor device does a poor job of detecting my skin. As it will take 5-6 times or more sometimes, for it to give me the green light to continue. Other times i have no issues on the first detection. I have tried this with all areas of by body, thinking maybe it was a tan that was throwing it off, however, even when letting it detect skin in areas that never get sunlight, it still has an issue sometimes with detecting my skin color and unlocking. I know other reviewers have complained about having to buy new bulbs. For just my chest, it may take 20 or so flashes to complete. And the bulbs have a life of 1000+ flashes (if i remember correctly), and doing this once a week, well you can do the math, it should last a long time for my use.

I was actually surprised it's working as well as it is because I have a hard time following the schedule exactly and I also struggle with the patience to get the treatment sections perfectly spaced with no overlap and no gaps. Because I've been a little haphazard in my approach (though generally following the instructions), I found that I have to go back and treat small patched that I obviously missed along the way, but I have no complaints about that. At this point, the bikini areas I've treated are perfectly hairless, and my underarms are probably 80% hairless because I have trouble with the placement and am going back over them. I wouldn't use this on large areas like legs... the treatment window is just too small! Overall, a great product for the price. Way cheaper and more convenient than paying for professional treatments, plus I get to keep the device for touch-ups. I've even lent it to a good friend who is also having great results.

  393. So, I've already had some laser hair removal done and was excited to get this machine for my arms and other spots that needed cleaning up. This machine hurts far less than laser hair removal typically, but if your hair is dark and dense (underarms/bikini) it will hurt and it will take longer to do. But it really hurts no more than a regular laser hair removal treatment from a professional. However, the area I was surprised it worked the best on is my arms. And it was virtually painless (mostly just hot). I think it works best on finer, darker hair like the arms and parts of the leg.<br /><br />I noticed some people complain that the light cartridge goes out sooner than advertised. I noticed that the cartridge goes out quicker on the higher heat setting, so if you are at 1 the whole time it will probably last as long as advertised. If you are at 5 about half the time. Also, the strength of the zaps decrease toward the end... so if you are doing a tougher area I would change the cartridge as soon as that light changes and not wait for it to go out.<br /><br />I also wanted people to know that I have some freckles on my arms. Enough that there is no real avoiding them when I did them. It was fine. I noticed nothing bad from it.

I didn't know she used it and one day I saw a hair under her arm and was going to pull it. she told me no that she would go home shave it off and use her laser on it. She said every time they do she cuts off the hair and zaps it and after a short time the hair is gone. I truly believe that this system after a while will give me the same results. Then there are more tender spots that make it feel like Satan's mistress herself came up just to punish you. I have yet to make it past the 3rd setting. I am genuinely terrified. The hardest part is keeping track of where you've used the laser on before. You have to shave the area and then use the laser. The best thing is to work in grid pattern. I laser the area, then wait an hour or so, run errands, whatever, and then I do it again. It's a bit expensive, but it's cheaper than going for 1 session at any laser place. I recommend it.

  431. The Remington Laser works wonders for me. FYI I have very coarse, dark hair. Evertyime I would shave the minute I stepped out of the shower I couldn't even tell I had shaved. I have done three treatments with it now and notice a drastic reduction in the hair on my legs and bikini line. The hair is either gone or there are only thin, light colored ones left behind. It does take a couple of weeks for the hair to fall out so don't expect to see results right away. I had the same experience with professional treatments anyways (at least for me). The laser does get less painful the more treatments you do and I imagine that is because there is less hair follicles for it to reach.<br /><br />I will say that it is easy to miss spots because I avoid stacking (using the laser on the same patch of skin >1 in a session) which could result in harming your skin. Also, it is difficult to get the shins and ankle areas because of the safety on it which ensures that you have it completely pressed against the skin. I have found that if I turn it sideways it is easier to get these difficult areas.<br /><br />All-in-all, a great purchase and I am very satisified. Thank you Remington!
  432. I have been using the I-Light once a week (on max power) for about 8 weeks. Yes, this is much more often than the directions indicate, but I have difficult to remove hair. I am very fair skinned with very dark hair. Hair removal creams don't work at all for me and I must shave every single day. I began using this system excusively in the bikini area to prepare for a trip this Spring. For the first 3-4 treatments, I saw ZERO results. After the fourth treatment, I began to notice a reduction. My bikini area is almost where I want it to be after 8 weeks so I am starting on the rest of my legs. I believe I will always have to treat weekly to maintain any kind of result as my hair growth is much faster than most womens (when I use a razor, i get a 5o'clock shadow on my legs!!). I am willing to continue to treat every week to avoid the daily use of a razor. So, based on other reviews, I would say you have to play around with the treatment levels to see what works for you...and you really have to stick it out to see results
  433. I was very skeptical about ordering this product. I wanted to go office hair removal but it seemed too expensive and time consuming so based on other reviews, I gave this product a try. I have medium to light skin and dark hair that grows on my chin, neck and upper lip. I used to tweeze all the time and wonder if a new hair popped up that I missed that someone else could see. My hair issues started pretty early, but got worse when I went off birth control and even worse after 30.<br /><br />I never wanted to shave my face or neck because I thought more hair would grow, well I don't think it makes more hair grow but if you have been tweezing, it makes all the hair surface at one time and that was difficult for me to deal with at first. I couldn't bear to shave for 6 weeks while I undid the effects of tweezing so I started shaving and the light treatments at the same time. I have been doing treatments for a few months now, every 2 weeks. At first I didn't notice a big difference but over time, a lot of the hair is gone and more and more is gone every time. I still need to shave, but it is so much better and I am very happy with the result. I think it's something that needs maintenance but it's so worth it for me.<br /><br />Does it hurt? I think I have a low pain tolerance and it does hurt a bit, but I use the highest setting because I want the biggest effect and it is still tolerable. It kind of feels like you are touching a hot curling iron for a second, but not enough to burn. I think the more hair you have, the more you feel it.<br /><br />How long does the cartridge last? It says 1,500 flashes. My warning light just came on after maybe 7 treatments. I do my under arms too.<br /><br />So, yes, I think this product is worth it. Just be patient and persistent.

I know) and I can already tell it's going to work. It doesn't feel nearly as painful as professional treatments but I'm okay with that haha! And yes, I will update on how this thing is working in a few months, but probably only if it's not working. So consider no news to be good news. Oh yeah this thing comes with a two year manufacturer warranty which is nice to know.<br /><br />1) I could smell the burnt hair during treatment, just like I did during the professional treatments.<br />2) Before treatment (last night), I would normally feel stubble regrowth within 24 hours after shaving. I'm pretty sure the hair follicles are dead, just as this product claims to do.<br /><br />I will absolutely spent $25 on cartridges. My prediction is I will go through 4 cartridges over the next 2 months, and then probably one every couple of months or so for touch ups. Hopefully fewer, but I am absolutely more than willing to pay the price. It is literally less than 1/10th of the cost of professional treatments, and probably will never add up the long run. To do underarms only, most places will charge $100 each treatment, and you need like 4-5! I can do a full body, twice, for $25!!! I'm just saying...<br /><br />I have light skin, dark hair - prime candidate (I apologize to you dark skinned gals, maybe they'll find a way!!) - and freckles - so far no burning or blistering!<br /><br />Pros:<br />-not messyat all like epilating and waxing, clean up is easy because there is no cleanup! Wipe the glass (cloth provided), unplug, and wrap the cord. No sticky wax and oil residue or little hairs all over the bathroom floor to sweep up.<br />-less time required for treatment. It took about 1.5 hours for full body, vs 2.5 hours epilating/waxing<br />-you don't have to let the hair grow out before treating it!! So you don't ever have to wear pants in July, or postpone that hot date again!!<br />-privacy! You can do your nether regions without having to bare all to a total stranger<br />-no razor burn, ingrown hairs, hairs growing long under the skin that you have to scrape out and pluck using tweezers<br />-laser hair removal lasts waaaaaaay longer than epilating and waxing does, you'll probably only have to shave maybe once a week, or once every other week and probably mainly only for the little blond hairs.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Nada!

I'm way too budget-conscious to spend $$$$ for a laser center hair removal treatment.   448. 2013.03.14 So far 95 % of my arm and leg hair is gone. In areas where the hair is courser like the bikini area it's down by 60% and facial hair is down by 35%. I have to send my unit in for warranty repair because flexing the cable makes it not work at times or cause the panel lights to flash.<br /><br />2013.02.05: 3rd session. Looking at my hair prior to treating it I noticed that about 50% of my arm and 30% of my leg hair isn't growing back now. Pubic hair maybe 20% reduced. It seems that the courser the hair is the more resistant it is. I'm keeping tabs on lamp life using my tips listed below which so far are working by preventing the lamp from overheating. Read \\"Extending Lamp Life\\" below.<br /><br />2013.01.18: I'm on my 2nd session which didn't make it halfway before the lamp wore out. It doesn't seem to last more than a few hundred flashes (not that I counted them). Could it be shipping damage? Dunno. I'll do some sample counting next time to estimate the number of flashes when the new lamps come. I think it might be my rapid fire use of it the first session that wore the lamp out faster. It did get quite warm but not to kick into overheat mode. In a couple places I have to turn it back to 3 so it didn't sting so much. The only thing I notice at this early stage is a bit of itching or irritation in spots. I'll see what happens in the next month...<br /><br />Original: I tried my first small session today and my impression is that it's plenty powerful enough and the unit build quality looks great. I wound up using level 4 and 5 with my pale skin and brown hair. Mostly it felt like a pinch with heat flash but a couple spots felt more like a shock and probably because of more hair follicles. They say that the higher the level you can stand the better it takes the hair out. Of course I'm judging the correct level by how each flash should typically feel as well as noticing if the skin is not being adversely harmed. After the session I don't feel any discomfort or notice any redness or injury at all on the treated areas.<br /><br />I've read some of the low star reviews before buying as I will do but many seem verging on hysteria, conspiracy, or don't know how to use the thing. If you're going to write a review good or bad keep it factual and sober otherwise it appears that you're making it up.<br /><br />IMPORTANT!: As the manual said, pull the nose off and check the lamp cart in case it came loose in shipping. Mine was loose and one pin was misaligned so I bent it straight and the cart seated in snugly. If I hadn't read that in the manual the unit wouldn't have worked.<br /><br />I'll update this review and star rating as I go with how it performs over the months...<br /><br />Extending Lamp Life<br />Some people complaint about short lamp life, which I too have experienced. I don't think it's a good design as far as keeping the lamp cool and the heat eventually makes it fail prematurely. My advise is to slow down how fast you flash the unit so that the flash tube stays cooler and doesn't fracture from overheating and don't block the air vents of the hand piece. I'm keeping the flash intervals at greater than 4 seconds with rest periods of a minute if I feel any little amount of warmth of the air venting out of the hand unit. Using a longer flash interval of probably 6 - 8 seconds would probably be okay for continuous use. Never get impatient and start flashing it fast for little stint, that could be all you need to overheat the tube. Leave the unit on and fan running if you take breaks in your session. Every bit of cooling will help. From my experience I think you'll be able to extend the lamp's life but it will still fail prematurely due to lots of tiny heat cracks forming in the tube to a point where they leak. My current lamp I estimate is getting close to it's maximum flash count using a 4 to 6 second flash interval but it still has developed a fine tangle of tiny fractures all around the cathode but none big enough to fail.<br /><br />In a nutshell the problem lies in the way the reflectors in front and behind the tube shroud it from the cooling air so it doesn't cool very fast because no real airflow is happening within the confines of the reflectors to cool the center section of the tube. It's a shame such a great product has this flaw, but at least it can be partially worked around. This unit really should have been designed with a much higher airflow to cool the lamp and maybe have incorporated some heatsinking.<br /><br />Other Tips to Extend the Lamp Life<br /><br />1, I keep cotton swabs and isopropyl alcohol on hand while using the unit, to clean the vaporized debris off of the lens whenever anything is seen on it.<br /><br />2, Between uses pull the hand unit nose off and see if the back of the lens and reflective surfaces are clean and shiny. Also look at the lamp's reflector. It may develop a haze on it. To clean that off I remove the lamp. hold it over a sink and have a small spray bottle with isopropyl alcohol in it that I spray the reflector and tube with. Then I carefully shake the alcohol off and use a hair dryer to dry the lamp off.<br /><br />Why the Lamp Fails (The technical version)<br /><br />The Xenon flash tube inside of the lamp if overheated develops small fractures that allow the gas inside to seep out. The cracks occur right around the tip of the cathode electrode which is the larger of the two inside the tube and the one that will heat up greatly since that's where the arcing starts. The intense blast of the arc and heat build up eventual causes the nearby quartz tube glass to fail.<br /><br />So other than the tube failing how does the unit know when the lamp has \\"expired\\" at 1,500 flashes? Well when I had the lamp apart I noticed a little \\"transistor\\" inside. I looked up the part number an it turns out to be a serially programmed EEPROM. Basically a tiny bit of memory that can store a number. The unit reads the number when turned on adds how many flashes you use and then loads the new number count back into that EEPROM. Apparently Remington deems the lamp's power level to be deteriorated enough at 1,500 flashes that it's out of spec as far as maintaining performance.o fail.<br /><br />In a nutshell the problem lies in the way the reflectors in front and behind the tube shroud it from the cooling air so it doesn't cool very fast because no real airflow is happening within the confines of the reflectors to cool the center section of the tube. It's a shame such a great product has this flaw, but at least it can be partially worked around. This unit really should have been designed with a much higher airflow to cool the lamp and maybe have incorporated some heatsinking.<br /><br />Other Tips to Extend the Lamp Life<br /><br />1, I keep cotton swabs and isopropyl alcohol on hand while using the unit, to clean the vaporized debris off of the lens whenever anything is seen on it.<br /><br />2, Between uses pull the hand unit nose off and see if the back of the lens and reflective surfaces are clean and shiny. Also look at the lamp's reflector. It may develop a haze on it. To clean that off I remove the lamp. hold it over a sink and have a small spray bottle with isopropyl alcohol in it that I spray the reflector and tube with. Then I carefully shake the alcohol off and use a hair dryer to dry the lamp off.<br /><br />Why the Lamp Fails (The technical version)<br /><br />The Xenon flash tube inside of the lamp if overheated develops small fractures that allow the gas inside to seep out. The cracks occur right around the tip of the cathode electrode which is the larger of the two inside the tube and the one that will heat up greatly since that's where the arcing starts. The intense blast of the arc and heat build up eventual causes the nearby quartz tube glass to fail.<br /><br />So other than the tube failing how does the unit know when the lamp has \\"expired\\" at 1,500 flashes? Well when I had the lamp apart I noticed a little \\"transistor\\" inside. I looked up the part number an it turns out to be a serially programmed EEPROM. Basically a tiny bit of memory that can store a number. The unit reads the number when turned on adds how many flashes you use and then loads the new number count back into that EEPROM. Apparently Remington deems the lamp's power level to be deteriorated enough at 1,500 flashes that it's out of spec as far as maintaining performance.
  449. So I have PCOS which means I'm way harrier than I would like. I bought this item in hopes that I could keep from having to avail myself of expensive laser treatment, and I am impressed. Now understand that I have very fair skin with dark terminal hair in places that I don't want it. I've now completed 3 treatments and the amount of hair in the treated areas is markedly reduced. What is more the remaining hair is growing at a much slower rate. Now I am not completely hairless in the treated areas, and I don't expect that I will obtain that type of result. However I have gone from having to pluck, shave, or use hair removal creams on a daily basis to only having to pluck every 3-4 days. It's the first time since I was 18 years old where I can go 3-4 days without plucking and still be able to leave the house without embarrassment. This is an outstanding result, and better than I was anticipating. And these are results that I have obtained while not following all the directions exactly (i.e. I continued to pluck hair even on the day of treatments, so I could have probably gotten better results if I had let my hair grow for the suggested 5-7 days worth of time before treatments, but I just couldn't bring myself to do this.)<br /><br />That being said there are some drawbacks- 1. I have already had to replace the flash-bulb that came with it, and I certainly hadn't used it the advertised 1500 times. 2. The design of the handheld device is awkward, it's a little bit too small to make treating large areas like legs easy. It is difficult to get it into a good position over curved areas as you have to make good contact with the skin before it will flash, and it is a little bit too large to treat smaller areas easily. I really wish that it came with several different size options, but what can you do. 3. This item will reduce hair, but it is not going to make you hairless, so if that is your goal you may want to try something different.
  450. I bought this last Feb (2012) and I love it. The first place I used it was on my face and it is such a relief not to have bleach, tweeze or wax any more and it only requires occasional touch-ups.<br />When I think of all the time, money and angst that I have spent over the years a measly $250 and 2 spare light bulbs is a very small price to pay for the results I have gotten.<br /><br />I have read some other reviews and I wonder about the dissatisfaction. It doesn't promise to immediately make all your hair disappear and it doesn't do that. It takes weeks and you have to have patience. If if was all that easy why would the \\"professionals\\" charge so much. Even when you have a professional do it you have to go back for touch-ups, it is a never ending process, just less frequent over time.<br /><br />This is one of my favorite purchases and only wish I had had it 20 years ago when I was in my 20s.

  481. I've been using this product for over a year. I'm only giving it a 4-star for two reasons: 1) I don't think the cartridges last as long as advertised. Some seem to last longer than others but I don't count the flashes. I just make sure I always have a replacement. But at $25 a pop, it's still a huge money saver over going to the aesthetician. In CA this has to be a registered nurse working under a doctor's supervision, so it is costly getting it done professionally.<br /><br />2) It simply doesn't work as fast as going to a professional. However, with the savings in mind, I don't mind that it might take twice as long, or 3 times or 4 times or more even! Let me put it this way, I spent over $1500 in professional treatments for only my chin and bikini line (both areas very narrowly defined), which worked great, but they were very small areas. The idea of doing my underarms, legs, or arms was out of the question financially.<br /><br />So both disadvantages are really irrelevant when you factor in the cost savings. Additionally the convenience of doing it at home, without having to make an appointment 2 weeks in advance is a huge advantage. Also, I can focus on stray or single hairs as I find them, which isn't really possible when you go into the salon. My entire *extended* bikini area is very clear now, with rarely a need to ever shave. I've worked on my underarms 3 or 4 times and it has reduced my shaving from once a day to once a week. I've worked on my legs 3 or 4 times, which is really hard to do thoroughly because of the irregular and large area, but this has reduced my shaving from daily to once or twice a week. And both underarms and legs are smoother after shaving and longer between shavings. Even my boyfriend noticed how smooth my underarms looked (after shaving, you could still see the black follicles).<br /><br />You are not supposed to use this on your face, but I do. Even professionally, the nurse could not completely eliminate all the chin hairs. She mentioned to me that chin hairs seemed really tough... But with this unit, I'm able to keep up on it and I've gone from plucking maybe 10-20 hairs a day to maybe seeing one or two a week, Which I clip short with a trimmer until I'm ready to use the unit. I also used it on stray eyebrow hairs and they have disappeared after only a few uses.<br /><br />As far as the best way to use it is concerned, I think you are reducing the effectiveness if you use it while the hairs are too long or too short. So I use it the day after I shave, so there is a little melanin/stubble just above the surface to draw the energy for the laser. But if the hair is too long, the energy is wasted burning the hair itself and less energy reaches the root of the hair. Also, you need to keep the reflective surface clean, and don't use cotton swabs (unless wrapped by the cloth that comes with the unit) or paper towels. The cleaner the surface, the better the energy is transmitted to the hair follicle.<br /><br />The other thing to keep in mind is that dark hair will respond best, and you may not realize that the hair on your legs or arms really isn't as dark as you think it may be. Which I think is what is going on with my legs. My legs are definitely smoother, and the area is hard to work on without missing spots, so it is taking awhile to do. But again, one treatment at the salon is $550. It would need a minimum of 3-4 treatments. That's over 2 grand! So if one cartridge at $25 does both my legs, and my legs end up requiring 10 treatments, that's only 10% the cost! But the reality is that I could do my legs (usually) 3 or 4 times with one cartridge.<br /><br />Now I see Remington is coming out with an even more powerful version. I think it's about $300 right now. I'm debating on getting that one now, because it's still a huge savings compared to going to the salon.<br /><br />In short, if you're a good candidate for laser hair removal, this is a great way to save a lot of money and practically clear away all your unwanted body hair. You just need to be patient and to use it properly.

  484. The product works but you have to have patience. I have not followed the directions so I give this review with a disclaimer: following my treatment process may cause harm to your skin with possible burns and scars. You follow my treatment process at your own risk. My treatment process may not work for everyone. This is basically the same disclaimer that comes with the package but it bears repeating since I admit to not following the directions but I am receiving good results.<br /><br />Here is what the product DOES NOT do: It does not work quickly, definitely NOT on blonde or white hair (don't even try), and if your skin is dark enough, at the time of use, you know, when you tan enough in the summer to get those nice white noticeable tan lines, then your skin may be too dark and the machine may not even turn on to use. Basically, it's for caucasians. That's not racist, it's just the way the technology works. The light is attracted to the dark hair follicle and basically burns it enough over time that it pretty much dies and the hair doesn't grow anymore or takes a super long time to grow back. (Hence, the reason that darker skin tones should not use the machine. Dark hair gets burned and so can dark skin; get it? ) And, yes, it can grow back but as I've said it can take a super long time. That's why you need maintenance treatments about every 6 months once the initial treatments are done.<br /><br />The directions say DO NOT use it on your face. I do, only because I know my skin and hair growth cycle and a plethora of other things about my dermatology that regular folks don't normally know. No, I'm not a doctor, just a 30 year veteran of suffering from ugly chin and mustache hair; since puberty. Thank you hormones. I was always at the high end of the normal range hormonally so no doctor would touch me hormonally for fear of turning me into a Yeti or maybe a man. I didn't want that either. So, depilatories (which I also don't recommend for the face; I learned the hard way), shaving, waxing, plucking, and electrolysis were my alternatives for the last 30 years. Yeah!<br /><br />The directions say use every 2 weeks for 6 weeks in a row and then when hair appears or every 6 months after for maintenance. I have been using it on my face every week (see disclaimer above) for about 8 weeks now and I am seeing results. I also use under my arms, which is allowed, and am seeing results there too. You must shave the area really close. Yeesh, back to that again. Do not use the product for at least an hour after shaving. Must be clean and dry, no deodorants or skin creams or even moisture. It works better if you're not sweating. Use a grid like pattern in the area you want to remove hair. It takes me about 15 minutes and about 50 pulses to do my chin, lip, and under arms. Yes, it stings, but less than electrolysis and the hair follicles don't get infected and cause pimples. I use setting 5. It might not sting on lower settings. I have high pain tolerance. To get the unit to even turn on you're supposed to put the body part to be pulsed on the sensor which is kind of weird because you would have to pick up the unit and put it under your arm or wherever. I just use my forearm. Exfoliate, exfoliate! Helps remove dead hair and keeps ingrowns at bay due to the shaving.<br /><br />My results: I had a couple of long hairs in sideburn area that are gone, my upper lip fine hairs are gone, and along my jawline are thinning out, as well as, my neck. White hairs I plucked and won't be back, they were dead anyway, no follicle attached. My under arms are also thinning. I have a couple of thick hairs at corners of my lip but I knew they'll take more time. Same as the other areas. Time, patience, and routine is a must. I cannot stress this enough.<br /><br />I know it's expensive but it's worth the investment considering my treatment at a dermatologist would cost me around $2,000 + considering my hair growth cycle and coarseness of hair. I did my researchand this is also an FDA approved product for home use. Do your own research and be an educated consumer. I just wanted everyone to know the product worked for me. I guess I could have said that in a shorter review but details sometimes mean the difference. Good luck!

I had planned to move on to larger areas such as the upper leg and bikini area. I think that this product is still a good investment as even going 10 weeks of being hair free makes life more convenient, but don't expect the same results as professional laser hair removal...in fact don't even expect 6 months of being hair free as the literature provided with this unit suggests. The amount of time to \\"zap\\" a few small areas after a shower is minimal and the refills are priced reasonably. I have used it on 5 for my chest and stomach, and started at 3 for my underarms and neck (up to my jawline, which is NOT recommended by Remington). I have since gone up to the full 5 everywhere, and the &#34;pain&#34; I get is trivial other than on my underarms.<br /><br />After 4 sessions, I find that the hair on my chest has thinned some but it still grows. My stomach hairs have gotten less course, but have not slowed growing at all.   498. I wasn't expecting much so I was pleased with the results I did get.<br /><br />I've completed about 3-4 treatments all most of the areas I wanted to treat. Full disclosure, I'm an ideal candidate for laser or IPL treatment - super pale of northern European decent and very dark hair. I done professional laser treatments twice. Once 10+ years ago on my face. It was fairly sucessful but some hair eventually came back. I did face again, plus toes, and tops of feet abut 5 years ago. Much more sucessful the second time around. Both times I did three plus treatments and spent well over $1,000 total. I wanted to do more at second place but was scared of the pain. The tops of my feet hurt like the dickens. I couldn't imagine doing bikini line without screaming at them to stop every other zap.<br /><br /> Having control is part of what really, really attracted me to IPL even tho I expected it to not work.<br /><br />But it did. After just one treatment on lower legs, I noticed hair was growing slower and less thick. Three treatments in, it's pretty amazing. Results ARE uneven. It strangely works better along the side of my shin bone but the top of my shin bone? Hair is still growing nearly as thick as always - even though I spend extra time and care zapping that area. Underarms have been most effective. The hair hardly grows any more.<br /><br />I think I'm pleased because I didn't expect perfect results. There is NO WAY the FDA would allow a company to sell a laser for home use because it is WAY TOO DANGEROUS. I expected this machine to be so under-powered it wouldn't do anything. It's not even a laser, just a strong light bulb flash. But, it's stronger than I expected. Using the IPL, the hairs almost never explode like they do with real laser treatment. I love the exploding hairs - hurts like crazy but you really feel that you've killed that hair forever. I think all this device does is stunt the hairs. I'll take the stunting. It's worth it to have to shave less.<br /><br />Like others have said, it's a pain the cartridges run out so fast. If I had to do it again, I may have bought the $400 version that has 30,000 flashes per cartrigdes but that's not very clear in the description. But, I do think the cartridge claiming 1,500 is more or less accurate. It's still way, way cheaper than professional hair removal of any mode - laser, waxing, etc.<br /><br />Edited to Add May 3, 2015<br />So... I bought a Tria. The Remington is fine but it only goes so far. The Tria has been much more effective on &#34;mid range&#34; hairs and hair that this thing just had no effect on. Save yourself some money and just do the Triia first Tria is more tedious because you only move it a quarter of an inch each time but it it's more effective. So in the long run, worth it.it's a pain the cartridges run out so fast. If I had to do it again, I may have bought the $400 version that has 30,000 flashes per cartrigdes but that's not very clear in the description. But, I do think the cartridge claiming 1,500 is more or less accurate. It's still way, way cheaper than professional hair removal of any mode - laser, waxing, etc. Edited to Add May 3, 2015 So... I bought a Tria. The Remington is fine but it only goes so far. The Tria has been much more effective on &#34;mid range&#34; hairs and hair that this thing just had no effect on. Save yourself some money and just do the Triia first Tria is more tedious because you only move it a quarter of an inch each time but it it's more effective. So in the long run, worth it.

  500. I actually bought this on a gamble, leaning more towards it not working.<br /><br />I'm a 23 year old male Hispanic with tan skin and have always been insecure about my thick leg hairs (Really f***ing thick)so $200 compared to paying a professional was more than appealing.<br /><br />First thing I tested it on was my hand and then my stomach, chest and a few days later, my legs. A lot of them fell out even with slight tugs, but some just kept growing. Turns out that about %50 of the hairs on my legs and stomach were completely unaffected.<br /><br />So after a full month, I'm pretty sure now that the hairs that did fall out are going to stay like that permanently, leaving the treated<br />areas looking all patchy. I can see and obvious pattern treatments so now I have to retreat it all again to completely get rid of the rest of the hairs.<br /><br />I was expecting to see hairs actually GROW back and thinner but, that wasn't the case at all. It's either going to kill the hair permanently or not affected at all. It's just hit or miss with some hair strands but, nothing future treatments won' be able to handle.<br /><br />If you want to completely get rid of hair, this will work for no doubt. As long as you're light skinned and have black hairs.<br />I found out why it doesn't work on darker skin when I treated my calfs, they're slightly darker and ended up with light burn marks.<br />for me, I don't mind that it was permanent but now I have to do it again as I can't leave the patches and lines of hairs growing.<br /><br />I HAVE PICTURES of before and after a month of the first treatment so if you want to see the patchworks,<br />E-mail me and I'll share. Thing will leave you bald if you do it like it's supposed to be done.

  504. I've had laser hair removal before (obviously I didn't complete the treatments) but wanted a less expensive way to obtaining similar results. I bought this instead of the Tria system [[ASIN:B0029OSN4U Tria Laser Hair Removal]] for two reasons: 1. the Tria is battery operated and I didn't want to deal with replacing (what are probably expensive) batteries, and 2. the Remington was significantly less expensive.<br /><br />I started using this several months ago and then sort of forgot to keep using it. The directions say to use every two weeks (which is the same frequency of treatment from actual laser hair removal businesses) and it's easy to forget. I recommend setting a calendar reminder to help you remember. Anyway, I *guess* I saw some hair loss? I did three full treatments but wasn't blow away.<br /><br />(BTW, the original cartridge lasted 3.5 treatments, include legs, bikini, underarm.)<br /><br />Maybe six weeks later I decided to give this another try. This time I concentrated only on the underarms and bikini because they're smaller (and quicker) areas to treat and I thought I would be able to test the effectiveness more efficiently.<br /><br />So, the results: I've done five or six treatments and am definitely seeing results in the bikini line. The underarms are okay but not as dramatic as the bikini area. I'm going to keep using it and see if I can get near complete hair removal, and I guess we'll see how long that lasts. Just keep with it - it's a slower process than professional laser hair removal, and the results are not as stunning, but then again the Remington is a fraction of the cost.<br /><br />Once I get the results I want, I'll move on and try this on my legs. The legs take A LONG TIME because the laser head is pretty small, so we'll see if I have the patience.

  506. I'm an olive-skinned, dark haired seasoned bikini waxer who's never tried professional laser hair removal due to the fact that it's expensive and I'm a little hairy so I was anxious to try the I-Light Pro. I read the I-Light Pro directions carefully and viewed the CD before using the unit. I haven't yet completed a full cycle but did see results with the first use. The instructions are thorough and easy to understand, the unit also has good safety features and is easy to use. On the downside, the I-Light cartridge that came with the unit died after the second use so I got no where near 1500 pulses or even 500 pulses (luckily I had a replacement cartridge). The other problem is the I-Light Pro overheats often so you have to wait for it to cool down before starting again. I didn't feel any real pain and can handle the I-Light Pro at its highest level. Different from waxing, the area covered is only about 1-inch so it takes much longer to complete an area verses waxing. Plus the I-Light Pro is not designed for semi-genitalia areas or face so I still have to wax those areas separately. Overall I am happy with my purchase. Remington is a good company and from what I've seen and read, they fully support their I-Light Pro, and the price was far more reasonable than their competitors. I'll report again after I've concluded a full cycle and how long before I see regrowth.

I am a male with fair/light skin and dark brown/black hair. I previously had wonderfully-permanent success with professional laser hair removal on my unibrow. I wanted to give this a try as a more cost-effective solution for other areas.<br /><br />Unfortunately, the unit didn't fail to work completely. Yes, it partially worked. I did six treatments each on several parts of my body including chest, arms, hands, feet, groin. I used the highest setting, and doing so is quite painful--albeit worth it had it actually worked. Treatment failed completely on all areas except for my chest/abdomen, where it partially worked. What do I mean by partially? Well, even though each treatment was done identically, apparently one of the treatments decided to actually work (probably had something to do with the growth cycle). Because I didn't line up each zap perfectly--impossible to do without serious overlap and, consequently, burn--I was left with a cheetah chest. There are about 24 rectangular patches where little-to-no hair grows now. Everywhere else around it, hair grows fine. If I let my hair grow out, it looks crazy. So now I must shave my chest religiously.<br /><br />I'm very disappointed in this product and have returned it for a partial refund. The experience I had with this device is 100% negative. I'm worse off than when I started. Would not wish this on my worst [hairy] enemy.

I bought this for my spouse 12/25/2012 - part of the deal is that I also administer the treatment - we're 60+ minutes from a skin center, so this seemed like a good idea.<br /><br />This product works as advertised - my spouse is fair-skinned and has dark folicles, so she's perfect for this unit. However, there are some considerations with this product that make it a pain in the tookus... I'll assume you've read the other 387 reviews and try to skip repeats ...<br /><br />Most Important / Best Tip:<br /><br />Put in a new cartridge refill and zap until it gives out - otherwise you won't get your $$$ worth from this thing. If you turn it off, or go for 1/2 sessions, the refill cartridge often won't &#34;accept your skin type,&#34; and you have to put in a new $18.00 refill to get going...<br /><br />*Every time you fire it up, you have to 'verify' that you are the proper skin type by holding it to your skin & hoping / praying that it decides to accept your skin, even though it worked just fine right before you took a break to get another ice bag ... if it decides you aren't the person you were just 10 minutes ago, the only resolution is to insert another $18.00 laser refill. I think it's .... odd at best that the refill just happens to punk-out after a session, and rarely during a session (we've only had one refill quit mid-session)<br /><br />*By our accounting, you get a certain number of pulses - give or take - depending on whether you screwed up and turned the thing off for a while - before you have to replace the bulb. It does not seem to matter what level of intensity the thing is on, so your best bet is to suffer & fry yourself. Ice packs are your friend.<br /><br />*Every time you turn the thing on, it starts at the lowest possible / least effective setting. I've gotten halfway through a treatment and realized &#34;@#$%^& - it's on LOW!&#34; and had to go back and do it again (NOT popular with the spouse, BTW..)<br /><br />*A waist - down treatment takes quite some time - as in 2-3 hours, as the window is the size of 1/2 of a postage stamp. I don't know how anyone does this to themselves without going blind - I have to move the unit, squeeze my eyes shut, & hit 'fire,' and I still see spots for an hour afterwards...<br /><br />***I'm not sure how to phrase this appropriately, so read carefully .... my lady does not like getting shot with a laser a few hundred times, but after the treatment, she's .... sparkier than usual? Out of curiosity, I had her do my shoulders, and I can say that getting shot with a laser over and over for some reason has a ... heightening effect on the 'ol libido. Sounds great, right? Well, unfortunately, after shooting my lady with a laser a few hundred times, and physically inspecting every square half-centimeter of her body for hair-folicles, and bombing my retinas with second-hand laser light again and again (sunglasses don't work, as you can't see with 'em on to operate the darn thing, so you have to just squeeze your eyes shut) ... well, after all that I can't say I'm particularly &#34;in the mood,&#34; and the same seemed to be the case when she was zapping me... go figure. So be prepared to either suppress your urges or take one for the team, depending on whether you're Han Solo or Princess Leia ....

  538. I received this a few weeks ago, so far I have done a few treatments with it, I have opted to go with the lower intensity during treatments in order to keep discomfort and rashes/irritations to a minimum.<br />As I am sure that most of you have read, results will not be immediately apparent, however, there does seem to be a change in two out of three areas that I am treating, the third area has thick stubborn hair so I expect it to take longer than the other two. On the areas with the somewhat thinner hair it seems that already there is a reduction of hair so that's very encouraging.<br /><br />On preparing the area, it is best to shave the area and make sure it is nice and dry, why?<br />1) even on the lowest setting the pulse puts out quite a bit of energy, wet skin would result in burns because of the heating up of the remaining water.<br />2) any hairs left will a-absorb energy that you really want to go in the follicle, and b-result in a burned hair smell.<br /><br />As far as the unit itself is concerned I had no issues with it what so ever, everything worked and still does.
  539. I purchased the i-Light Pro in March 2014. I used it on my underarms and bikini area first, as these were the areas I was most interested in NOT SHAVING anymore. I read (and mostly followed) the instructions. I determined I was a good candidate for the laser to work well -- dark hair with medium/olive complexion. The product is easy to use. It did smart a little more than I expected at first, but you do get used to it. Just like the instructions said, I saw the first signs of results about 2 weeks after my first use. I've used it about 4 times over 6 weeks on my underarms and they are 95% hair-free! yeah! I'm just touching up areas that I missed now. My bikini line is about 85% hair free and has required a few more touch-ups, but this could be because that area is more sensitive and I had to use a lower setting.<br /><br />My big question is how long these results will last. I had really hoped the results would be permanent, but the product does not make that promise. (It says &#34;up to 6 monthhs&#34;.) Another reviewer confirmed the 6 month figure before re-treatment was required. If that turns out to be accurate, I'll be happy to have had a hair-free summer and will re-treat in the fall. The treatments are quick on smaller areas like I've been doing -- 10 to 15 minutes max. Larger areas take longer, obviously, and are trickier to make sure you've covered adequately.<br /><br />I haven't had any of the technical problems some reviewers reported. I'm still using the original bulb and it's firing just fine. I have not been good about keeping track of the number of flashes, however, so will rely on the machine to tell me when it's nearing the end of it's life.<br /><br />Overall, I am very happy with this purchase and the results because a) the price is very reasonable compared to laser hair removal in a salon; b) I control the machine and my comfort level, avoiding the risk of severe burns/scars which can happen with salon treatments; and c) the results have been what I hoped for. If you are a good candidate and have enough patience to wait two weeks to see results, you will be happy with this product.sults have been what I hoped for. If you are a good candidate and have enough patience to wait two weeks to see results, you will be happy with this product.

  542. Let me start by saying that I've had professional laser hair removal and purchased this product much more as a spot reducer than to really do hair removal on my entire body. The product is study, well-made, and easy to use. Why I would NOT recommend this product to anyone is that it does not emit the advertised 1,500 pulses per cartridge. I use it merely for single or few hairs on a few body parts and have gone through numerous cartridges when if the advertised number of pulses were true I would hypothetically still be on my first cartridge. At 25 dollars a pop for the cartridge it's no longer an economically beneficial product and I'd suggest that anyone debating getting laser hair removal would be better off looking for a professional. Nothing irks me more than blatant false advertising and there is no way Remington does not know that the cartridge doesn't last 1,500 pulses. It's essentially part of their marketing plan, to get you to buy the system and then rely on the revenue generated from the cartridges over the course of time....Sleazy

  556. I think you can get a more effective laser hair treatment with a professional. Always max it out - especially since you only get 1500 light pulses per cartridge. I think the cartridges are much more powerful when you initially start using them, so over time you will probably use more pulses for an area and still have a sub par experience. The good news is the cartridges are relatively inexpensive compared to similar products from competitors.<br /><br />UPDATE: I knocked some stars off. Despite continued use, the hair keeps coming back. The hair is much, much finer, but it's all still there. I recently went to a professional for my neck line, and if the pain levels are any indication of what an effective treatment is like, it's the equivalent of 5-6 pulses from this device on the same area. After 1 professional treatment, over 80% of my hair did not grow back in 6 weeks time. So when all is said and done, get yourself a laser hair removal deal from Yelp. It might cost a little more, but your time and effort will be worth something in the end if a professional does it.

I do use the red (incredibly nerdy) laser-glasses things, but then I have sensitive eyes and I use them any time I use this machine, no matter where.<br /><br />The break-down of how I use/used it is:<br /><br />It actually took me a bit before I worked up the courage to actually use the ILight, because I was convinced it would HURT! But, to be honest, it really doesn't (even on my face!). The one rule I do follow is I shave right before using it and I have little to no pain after. Sure, I always manage to miss a spot or five when shaving and those areas are painful – for about three seconds – but on the whole it is pain free, and I'm on #5! Obviously, that will be different for every person, but I think that if you've ever gotten a wax or even nicked yourself shaving you’ll probably find this less painful.<br /><br />So, for the first week I used it every day on my face (beard/mustache area) because I was super frustrated, breaking out from the fuzz, had bumps from plucking, etc., and wanted to be very aggressive. I was just done with the awkward facial hair and willing to take the risk. The next week I used it basically every other day, and now I just use it two/three times a week – or whenever I have time or remember. I'm not regimented about it. This is the first thing that's worked for my facial hair and it's BRILLIANT. There is so much less hair it’s unreal – and in some areas, areas I’ve been plucking for years (like, there was a lot of hair there), the hair is totally gone! That alone is worth the price of the ILight and the cartridges for me, to be honest.<br /><br />If you're a woman like me dealing with this, know that it works and that others are going through/have gone through what you are. (I was at my wits end when I stumbled on this and wanted to know the above info when I was reading reviews, so that's why I included so much info. I hope it helps you, if you're looking for something, anything that works, like I was.)<br /><br />But, caveat emptor: Remington flat out says don't use it on your face. That’s a choice you’ll have to make for yourself.<br /><br />Now, moving on to the rest, because you can bet that for the money I spent I'm using it everywhere... it's great. I haven't been as aggressive with my body hair as with my facial hair (because, God, who has the patience!) but it's really working, just slower. I use it about once a week (maybe once every two weeks if I'm busy) and the hair is really going away. Less hair grows back and a lot of the hair just falls out when I lightly tug on it, which is awesome.<br /><br />So, all in all, in case it wasn’t glaringly obvious yet, I’m a big fan. I’m super grateful I stumbled on this and actually got it. For me, it’s a life saver. Good luck!<br /><br />P.S. Remington’s customer service is STELLAR! If you have any issue they are there for you. Their customer service reps are incredibly nice and lovely to deal with – which is basically just gilding the lily!

  577. I would say it kind of works. People need to remember that the system pushes out the hair after it dies... it doesn't just fall out, and because hair grows in stages, not every hair [under your arm or on your leg] is actively growing at once. It may seem so, but it's not. So the 6 week treatment plan is there to make sure it gets all the hair no matter the cycle. And honestly, I'd give it more like 8+ weeks. People that constantly shave seem to forget just how LONG this hair is. Remember, it's being pushed out, and the hair is what - probably 2 inches long or so under your arms if you let it grow, right? That would take a while. I, myself do not have perfectly taut skin, and due to the nature of the product, it's difficult to get the light where it needs to be (plus, it's pretty easy to miss spots!). Where my skin is taut it works great. Where it's not, my hair is still growing or being pushed out, I'm not sure which. But, it is lighter and softer than before. Shaving under my arms takes like 10 seconds. Is it worth 200+? Eh. I guess it depends on how much your abhor shaving. And yeah, it can also be kind of painful, but I think that part is worth it.

  586. Just did my second treatment and already I notice a HUGE difference in hair growth! Some areas of the body are a little more tender than others....it feels like a \\"zap!\\" so don't turn the system up until you have tested it. Awesome product <3
  587. I followed the instructions exactly as described.. Six month after first treatment (that is 1st week, 3rd week and 5th week), hair reduction is more than 60%. I am starting my second treatment. Used 2 cartridges for 1st treatment (3 times full leg, bikini line and underarms). I recommend to follow instructions exactly as described in the user manual and have at least 1 spare cartridge so you do not have to wait for it during your treatment.
  588. This is really a great product. Does just what it says it will. Need more time to do my whole leg, eventually.
  589. I haven't been using the I-Light Pro every week like it recommends. However, the few times I have used it have reduced the amount of hair regrowth in my bikini line and underarms! The hair is more sparse, and takes longer to grow back. I will continue using it and update my review in the future.<br /><br />But for now, to discuss how it works, it turns on and is ready for the &#34;Skin tone check&#34; quickly. You just place it on the part of the skin you plan to 'zap' and cover the little opening on the base to check that the skin tone in that area is acceptable. Then you can start zapping away. There is a small delay in between flashes while it recharges for the next zap. Also, I highly recommend trimming the hair as short as possible or shaving as close as possible before working on an area. Otherwise, to me, it feels like you feel the zap more if you don't and you get that awful smell of burnt hair, on top of the fact that it gets the little glass face dirtier if you don't shave or trim first.<br /><br />I have a fairly strong tolerance for pain, and the flashes around my bikini area make me jump and cringe at the next one. So you do feel it. And this was only on the second strongest setting. I'm not sure how others crank this puppy up to high and use it on sensitive areas! But it would get the job done faster. =o)<br /><br />Also, even though this isn't approved for the face, I have used it on my upper lip. It is a tight fit, and not easy to make sure you get really close to the lip area. However, it worked great there! The still hasn't grown back in over a month. I have a medium skin tone, and I didn't have any issues at all on any of the places I used it.<br /><br />Overall, I'm very happy with this purchase, as it has reduced the hair growth, even though it hasn't fully eliminated my need for shaving. I will continue using it and look forward to getting more long term results. It is definitely cheaper than going to 6-8 sessions at a professional laser hair removal place! And you can do it in the comfort of your home and whenever you have 10-15 minutes of free time.
  590. I have been using this for a few months now. Being a fairly hairy man I wasn't sure what to expect from this product. The areas where I use it are too sensitive for waxing. Waxing and sugaring just tear up my skin for a couple weeks after. Nair burns the sensitive areas, and the hair grows back soon anyway.<br /><br />I have not been using as often as I could, but the results are still impressive. Armpit hair is practically gone. What little pubic hair remains is VERY slow growing.<br /><br />Good quality product that works as described!!
